Now it was standing between the two cars. Tim could n't see Dr. Grant's car any more, because the huge body blocked his (Tim) view. The rain ran in riv ulets down the pebbled skin of the muscular hind legs. He (Tim) couldn't see the animal's head, which was high above the roofline. The tyrannosaur moved around the side of their car. It went to the very spot where Tim had gotten out of the car. Where Ed Regis had gotten ou t of the car. The animal paused there. The big head ducked down, toward the mud. Tim looked back at Dr. Grant and Dr. Malcolm in the rear car. Their faces were tense as they stared forward through the windshield. The huge head raised back up, jaws open, and then s topped by the side windows. In the glare of lightning, they saw the beady, expressionless re ptile eye moving in the socket. It was looking in the car. His (Tim) sister's breath came in ragged, frightened gasp s. He (Tim) reached out and squeezed her (sister) arm, hoping she (sister) would stay quiet. The dinosaur continued to stare for a long time through the side window. Perhaps the dinosaur couldn't really see th em, he (Tim) thought. Finally the head lifted up, out of view again.

``Timmy ...'' (Lex)
Lex whispered.
``It's okay,'' (Tim)
Tim whispered.
``I don't think it saw u s.'' (He)
He (Tim) was looking back toward Dr. Grant when a jolting impact rocked the Land Cruiser and shattered the windshield in a spiderweb as the tyra nnosaur's head crashed against the hood of the Land Cruiser. Tim was knocked flat on the seat. The night-vision goggles slid off his (Tim) forehead. He (Tim) got back up quickly, blinking in the darkness, h is mouth warm with blood.
``Lex?'' (He)
He (Tim) couldn't see his (Tim) sister anywhere. The tyrannosaur stood near the front of the Land Cr uiser, its chest moving as it breathed, the forelimbs making clawing movements in the air.
``Lex!'' (Tim)
Tim whispered. Then he (Tim) heard her (sister) groan. She (sister) was lying somewhere on the floor under the front seat. Then the huge head came down, entirely blocking the shattered windshield. The tyrannosaur banged again on the front hood of the Land Cruiser. Tim grabbed the seat as the car rocked on its wheels. The tyrannosaur banged down twice more, denting the metal. Then it moved around the side of the car. The big r aised tail blocked his (Tim) view out of all the side windows. At the back, the animal snorted, a deep ru mbling growl that blended with the thunder. It sank its jaws into the spare tire mounted on the ba ck of the Land Cruiser and, in a single head shake, tore it away. The rear of the car lifted int o the air for a moment; then it thumped down with a

muddy splash.

``Tim!'' (Dr. Grant)
Dr. Grant said.
``Tim, are you there?'' (Tim)
Tim grabbed the radio.
``We're okay,'' (he)
he (Tim) said. There was a shrill metallic scrape as claws raked the roof of the car. Tim's heart was pounding in his (Tim) chest. He (Tim) couldn't see anything out of the windows on the right side except pebbled leathe ry flesh. The tyrannosaur was leaning against the car, which rocked back and forth with each brea th, the springs and metal creaking loudly. Lex groaned again. Tim put down the radio, and star ted to crawl over into the front seat. The tyrannosaur roared and the metal roof dented downwa rd.. Tim felt a sharp pain in his (Tim) head and tumbled to the floor, onto the transmission bump. H e found himself lying alongside Lex, and he (Lex) was shocked to see that the whole side of her (Tim) head was covered in blood. She (Tim) looked unconscious. There was another jolting impact, and pieces of gla ss fell all around him (Lex). Tim felt rain. He (Tim) looked up and saw that the front windshield had bro ken out. There was just a jagged rim of glass and, beyond, the big head of the dinosaur. Looking down at him (Tim). Tim felt a sudden chill and then the head rushed fo rward toward him (Tim), the jaws open. There was the squeal of metal against teeth, and he (Tim) felt the hot stinking breath of the animal and a thick tongue stuck into the car through the windshield op ening. The tongue slapped wetly around inside the car-he felt the hot lather of dinosaur s aliva-and the tyrannosaur roared-a deafening sound inside the car- The head pulled away abruptly. Tim scrambled up, avoiding the dent in the roof. Th ere was still room to sit on the front seat by the passenger door. The tyrannosaur stood in the ra in near the front fender. It seemed confused by what had happened to it. Blood dripped freely fr om its jaws. The tyrannosaur looked at Tim, cocking its head to stare with one big eye. The head moved close to the car, sideways, and peered in. Blood sp attered on the dented bood of the Land Cruiser, mixing with the rain. It can't get to me, Tim thought. It's too big. Then the head pulled away, and in the flare of ligh tning he (Tim) saw the hind leg lift up. And the world tilted crazily as the Land Cruiser slammed ov er its side, the windows splatting in the mud. He (Tim) saw Lex fall helplessly against the side window, and he (Lex) fell down beside her (its), banging his (Lex) head. Tim felt dizzy. Then the tyrannosaur's jaws c lamped onto the window frame, and the whole Land Cruiser was lifted up into the air, and shaken .
``Timmy!'' (Lex)
Lex shrieked, so near to his (Lex) ear that it h urt. She (its) was suddenly awake, and he (Lex) grabbed her (its) as the tyrannosaur crashed the car down again. Tim felt a stabbing pain in his (Tim) side, and his (Tim) sister fell on top of him (Tim). The car went up again, tilting crazily. Lex shouted
``Timmy!'' (Lex)
and he (Lex)

saw the door give way beneath her (sister), and she (sister) fell out of the car into the mud but Tim couldn't answer, because in the next instant everything swun g crazily-he saw the trunks of the palm trees sliding downward past him-moving sideways through t he (Tim) air-he glimpsed the ground very far below-the hot roar of the tyrannosaur-the blazing e ye-the tops of the palm trees- And then, with a metallic scraping shriek, the car fell from the tyrannosaur's jaws, a sickening fall, and Tim's stomach heaved in the moment before the world became totally black, and silent. In the other car, Malcolm gasped.

``Jesus! What happ ened to the car?'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant blinked his (Grant) eyes as the lightning faded. The other car was gone. Grant couldn't believe it. He (Grant) peered forward, tryin g to see through the rain-streaked windshield. The dinosaur's body was so large, it was probably j ust blocking- No. In another flash of lightning, he (Grant) saw clearly: the car was gone.
``What happened?'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)
Malcolm said.
``I don't know.'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Faintly, over the rain, Grant heard the sound of th e little girl screaming. The dinosaur was standing in darkness on the road up ahead, but they could see well enough to know that it was bending over now, sniffing the ground. Or eating something on the ground.
``Can you see?'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)
Malcolm said, squinting.
``Not much, no,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. The rain pounded on the roof of the car. He (Grant) listened for the little girl, but he (Grant) didn't hear her (girl) any more. The two men sat in the car, listening.
``Was it the girl?'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)
Malcolm said, finally.
``It sound ed like the girl.'' (unknown)
``It did, yes.'' (unknown)
``Was it?'' (unknown)
``I don't know,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. He (Grant) felt a seeping fatig ue overtake him (Grant). Blurred through the rainy windshield, the dinosaur was coming toward their ca r. Slow, ominous strides, coming right toward them. Malcolm said,
``You know, at times like this one fee ls, well, perhaps extinct animals should be left extinct. Don't you have that feeling now?'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)
``Yes,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. He (Grant) was feeling his (Grant) heart poundin g.
``Umm. Do you, ah, have any suggestions about what w e do now?'' (He)
``I can't think of a thing,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. Malcolm twisted the handle, kicked open the door, a nd ran. But even as he (Malcolm) did, Grant could see he (Grant) was too late, the tyrannosaur too close. The re was another crack of lightning, and in that instant of glaring white light, Grant watched in ho rror as the tyrannosaur roared, and leapt forward. Grant was not clear about exactly what happened nex t. Malcolm was running, his (Malcolm) feet splashing in the mud. The tyrannosaur bounded along side him (Malcolm) and ducked its massive head, and Malcolm was tossed into the air like a small doll. By then Grant was out of the car, too, feeling the cold rain slashing his (Grant) face and body. The tyrannosaur had turned its back to him (Grant), the huge ta il swinging through the air. Grant was tensing to run for the woods when suddenly the tyrannosaur spu n back to face him (Grant), and roared. Grant froze. He (Grant) was standing beside the passenger door of the La nd Cruiser, drenched in rain. He (Grant) was completely exposed, the tyrannosaur no more than ei ght feet away. The big animal roared again. At so close a range the sound was terrifyingly loud . Grant felt himself shaking with cold and fright. He (Grant) pressed his (Grant) trembling hands against the metal of the door panel to steady them. The tyrannosaur roared once more, but it did not at tack. It cocked its head, and looked with first one eye, then the other, at the Land Cruiser. And it did nothing. It just stood there. What was going on? The powerful jaws opened and closed. The tyrannosau r bellowed angrily, and then the big hind leg came up and crashed down on the roof of the car ; the claws slid off with a metal screech, barely missing Grant as he (Grant) stood there, still unmov ing. The foot splashed in the mud. The head ducked down in a slow arc, and the animal inspected the car, snorting. It peered into the front windshi eld. Then, moving toward the rear, it banged the passenger door shut, and moved right toward Grant a s he (Grant) stood there. Grant was dizzy with fear his (Grant) heart pounding inside his (Grant) chest. With the anima l so close, he (Grant) could smell the rotten flesh in the mouth, the sweetish blood-smell, the sickening stench of the carnivore... . He (Grant) tensed his (Grant) body, awaiting the inevitable. The big head slid past him (Grant), toward the rear of the car. Grant blinked. What had happened? Was it possible the tyrannosaur hadn't seen him (Grant)? It seemed as if it hadn't. But how could that be? Grant looked back to see the animal sniffing th e rear-mounted tire. It nudged the tire with its snout, and then the head swung back. Again it appro ached Grant. This time the animal stopped, the black flaying nos trils just inches away. Grant felt the animal's startling hot breath on his (Grant) face. But the tyrannosa ur wasn't sniffing like a dog. It was just breathing, and if anything it seemed puzzled. No, the tyrannosaur couldn't see him (Grant). Not if he (Grant) sto od motionless. And in a detached academic corner of his (Grant) mind he (Grant) found an explanation for that , a reason why- The laws opened before him (Grant), the massive head raised up. Grant squeezed his (Grant) fists together, and bit his (Grant) lip, trying desperately to remain motio nless, to make no sound. The tyrannosaur bellowed in the night air. But by now Grant was beginning to understand. The a nimal couldn't see him (Grant), but it suspected he (Grant) was there, somewhere, and was trying with its be llowing to frighten Grant into some revealing movement. So long as he (Grant) stood his (Grant) ground, Grant rea lized, he (Grant) was invisible. In a final gesture of frustration, the big hind leg lifted up and kicked the Land Cruiser over, and Grant felt searing pain and the surprising sensatio n of his (Grant) own body flying through the air. It seemed to be happening very slowly, and he (Grant) had plen ty of time to feel the world turn colder, and watch the ground rush up to strike him (Grant) in the face.

Return

``Oh damn,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said.
``Will you look at that.'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
They were sitting in Harding's gasoline-powered Jee p, staring forward past the flick flick of the windshield wipers. In the yellow flare of the headl amps, a big fallen tree blocked the road.
``Must have been the lightning,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``Hell of a tree.'' (unknown)
``We can't get past it,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said.
``I better tel l Arnold in control.'' (He)
He (Harding) picked up the radio and twisted the channel dial.
``Hello, John. Are you the re, John?'' (unknown)
There was nothing but steady hissing static.
``I don 't understand,'' (he)
he (Harding) said.
``The radio lines seem to be down.'' (unknown)
``It must be the storm,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said. ``I

suppose,'' Harding said. ``Try the Land Cruisers,'' Ellie said. Harding opened the other channels, but there was no answer. ``Nothing,'' he (Harding) said. ``They're probably back to camp by now, and outside the range of our little set. In any case, I don't think we should stay here . It'll be hours before Maintenance gets a crew out here to move that tree.'' He (Harding) turned the radio off, and put the Jeep into reve rse. ``Wbat're you going to do?'' Ellie said. ``Go back to the turnout, and get onto the maintenan ce road. Fortunately there's a second road system,'' Harding explained. ``We have one road for v isitors, and a second road for animal handlers and feed trucks and so on. We'll drive bac k on that maintenance road. It's a little longer. And not so scenic. But you may find it interesting. If the rain lets up, we'll get a glimpse of some o f the animals at night. We should be back in thirty, forty minutes,'' Harding said.

``If I don't get lost. '' (unknown)
He (Harding) turned the Jeep around in the night, and headed south again. Lightning flashed, and every monitor in the control room went black. Arnold sat forward, his (Arnold) body rigid and tense. Jesus , not now. Not now. That was all he (Arnold) needed- to have everything go out now in the storm. All the main power circuits were surge-protected, of course, but Arnold wasn't sure about the modems Ned ry was using for his (Arnold) data transmission. Most people didn't know it was possible to blow an entire system through a modem-the lightning pulse climbed back into the computer through the te lephone line, and-bang!-no more motherboard. No more RAM. No more file server. No m ore computer. The screens flickered. And then, one by one, they c ame back on. Arnold sighed, and collapsed back in his (Arnold) chair. He (Arnold) wondered again where Nedry had gone. Five minute s ago, he (Nedry)'d sent guards to search the building for him (Nedry). The fat bastard was probably in t he (bastard) bathroom reading a comic book. But the guards hadn't come back, and they hadn't called in.

Five minutes. If Nedry was in the building, they sh ould have found him (Nedry) by now.

``Somebody took the damned Jeep,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said as he (Muldoon) came back in the room.
``Have you talked to the Land Cruisers yet?'' (unknown)
``Can't raise them on the radio,'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said.
``I ha ve to use this, because the main board is down. It's weak, but it ought to work. I've tried o n all six channels. I know they have radios in the cars, but they're not answering.'' (unknown)
``That's not good,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``If you want to go out there, take one of the maint enance vehicles.'' (unknown)
``I would,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said,
``but they're all in the ea st garage, more than a mile from here. Where's Harding?'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
``I assume he (Harding)'s on his (Harding) way back.'' (unknown)
``Then he (Harding)'ll pick up the people in the Land Cruisers on his (Harding) way.'' (unknown)
``I assume so.'' (unknown)
``Anybody tell Hammond the kids aren't back yet?'' (unknown)
``Hell no,'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said.
``I don't want that son of a bitch running around here, screaming at me. Everytbing's all right, for the moment. The Land Cr uisers are just stuck in the rain. They can sit a while, until Harding brings them back. Or until we find Nedry, and make that little bastard turn the systems back on.'' (unknown)
``You can't get them back on?'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. Arnold shook his (Arnold) head.
``I've been trying. But Nedry 's done something to the system. I can't figure out what, but if I have to go into the code itself, that'll take hours. We need Nedry. We've got to find the son of a bitch right away.'' (Nedry/Dennis Nedry/Dennis)
Nedry The sign said ELECTRIFIED FENCE 10,000 VOLTS DO NOT TOUCH, but Nedry opened it with his (Nedry) bare band, and unlocked the gate, swinging it w ide. He (Nedry) went back to the Jeep, drove through the gate, and then walked back to close it behind h im. Now he (Nedry) was inside the park itself, no more than a m ile from the east dock. He (Nedry) stepped on the accelerator and bunched forward over the steering w heel, peering through the rain-slashed windshield as he (Nedry) drove the Jeep down the narrow roa d. He (Nedry) was driving fast-too fast-but he (Nedry) had to keep to his (Nedry) timetable. He (Nedry) was surrounded on all sid es by black jungle, but soon he (Nedry) should be able to see the beach and the ocean off to his (Nedry) left . This damned storm, he (Nedry) thought. It might screw up ev erything. Because if Dodgson's boat wasn't waiting for him (Dodgson) at the east dock when Nedry got there, the whole plan would be ruined. Nedry couldn't wait very long, or he (Nedry) would be misse d back at the control room. The whole idea behind the plan was that he (Nedry) could drive to the east dock, drop off the embryos, and be back in a few minutes, before anyone noticed. It was a good p lan, a clever plan. Nedry'd worked on it carefully, refining every detail. This plan was goi ng to make him (Nedry) a million and a half dollars, one point five meg. That was ten years of income in a s ingle tax-free shot, and it was going to change his (Nedry) life. Nedry'd been damned careful, even to the point of making Dodgson meet him (Dodgson) in the San Francisco airport at the last minute with an excuse about wanting to see the money, Actually, Nedry wanted to record his (Nedry) conversation with Dodgso n, and mention him (Nedry) by name on the tape. Just so that Dodgson wouldn't forget he (Dodgson) owed the re st of the money, Nedry was including a copy of the tape with the embryos. In short, Nedry had thou ght of everything. Except this damned storm. Something dashed across the road, a white flash in his (Nedry) headlights. It looked like a large rat. It scurried into the underbrush, dragging a fat tail. Possum. Amazing that a possum could survive here. You'd think the dinosaurs would get an animal like that. Where was the damned dock? He (Nedry) was driving fast, and he (Nedry)'d already been gone fiv e minutes. He (Nedry) should have reached the east dock by now. Had he (Nedry) taken a wrong turn? He (Nedry) did n't think so. He (Nedry) hadn't seen any forks in the road at all. Then where was the dock? It was a shock when he (Nedry) came around a corner and saw that the road terminated in a gray concrete barrier, six feet tall and streaked dark w ith rain. He (Nedry) slammed on the brakes, and the Jeep fishtailed, losing traction in an end-to-end s pin, and for a horrified moment he (Nedry) thought he (Nedry) was going to smash into the barrier-he knew he (Nedry) was going to smash-and he (Nedry) spun the wheel frantically, and the Jeep slid to a stop, the headl amps just a foot from the concrete wall. He (Nedry) paused there, listening to the rhythmic flick of the wipers. He (Nedry) took a deep breath and exhaled slowly. He (Nedry) looked back down the road. He (Nedry)'d obviously taken a wrong turn somewhere. He (Nedry) could retrace his (Nedry) steps, but that would take too long. He (Nedry)'d better try and find out where the hell he (Nedry) was.

He (Nedry) got out of the Jeep, feeling heavy raindrops spa tter his (Nedry) head. It was a real tropical storm, raining so hard that it hurt. He (Nedry) glanced at his (Nedry) wat ch, pushing the button to illuminate the digital dial. Six minutes gone. Where the hell was he (Nedry)? He (Nedry) w alked around the concrete barrier and on the other side, along with the rain, he (Nedry) heard the sound of gurgling water. Could it be the ocean? Nedry hurried forward, his (Nedry) eyes adjusting to the da rkness as he (Nedry) went. Dense jungle on all sides. Raindrops slapping on the leaves. The gurgling sound became louder, drawing him (Nedry) forwa rd, and suddenly he (Nedry) came out of the foliage and felt his (Nedry) feet sink into soft earth and saw the dark currents of the river. The river! He (Nedry) was at the jungle river! Damn, he (Nedry) thought. At the river where? The river ran for miles through the island. He (Nedry) looked at his (Nedry) watch again. Seven minutes gone.

``You have a pr oblem, Dennis,'' (he)
he (Nedry) said aloud. As if in reply, there was a soft hooting cry of an owl in the forest. Nedry hardly noticed; he (Nedry) was worrying about his (Nedry) pla n. The plain fact was that time had run out. There wasn't a choice any more. He (Nedry) had to abandon h is original plan. All he (Nedry) could do was go back to the control room, restore the computer, and somehow try to contact Dodgson, to set up the drop at the east dock for the following night. Nedry would have to scramble to make that work, but he (Nedry) thought he (Nedry) could pull it off. The comp uter automatically logged all calls; after Nedry got through to Dodgson, he (Nedry)'d have to go back into t he (Nedry) computer and erase the record of the call. But one thing was sure-he couldn't stay out in the park any longer, or his (Nedry) absence would be noticed. Nedry started back, heading toward the glow of the car's headlights. He (Nedry) was drenched and miserable. He (Nedry) heard the soft booting cry once more, and this time he (Nedry) paused. That hadn't really sounded like an owl. And it seemed to be close by, in the jungle somewhere off to his (Nedry) right. As he (Nedry) listened, he (Nedry) heard a crashing sound in the un derbrush. Then silence. He (Nedry) waited, and heard it again. It sounded distinctly like somethin g big, moving slowly through the jungle toward him (Nedry). Something big. Something near. A big dinosaur. Get

out of here. Nedry began to run. He (Nedry) made a lot of noise as he (Nedry) ra n, but even so he (Nedry) could hear the animal crashing through the foliage. And hooting. It was coming closer. Stumbling over tree roots in the darkness, clawing his (Nedry) way past dripping branches, he (Nedry) saw the Jeep ahead, and the lights shining around the verti cal wall of the barrier made him (Nedry) feel better. In a moment he (Nedry)'d be in the car and then he (Nedry)'d get the h ell out of here. He (Nedry) scrambled around the barrier and then he (Nedry) froze. The animal was already there. But it wasn't close. The dinosaur stood forty feet away, at the edge of the illumination from the headlamps. Nedry hadn't taken the tour, so he (Nedry) hadn' t seen the different types of dinosaurs, but this one was strange-looking. The ten-foot-tall bod y was yellow with black spots, and along the head ran a pair of red V-shaped crests. The dinosau r didn't move, but again gave its soft hooting cry. Nedry waited to see if it would attack. It didn't. Perhaps the headlights from the Jeep frightened it,

forcing it to keep its distance, like a fire. The dinosaur stared at him (Nedry) and then snapped its hea d in a single swift motion. Nedry felt something smack wetly against his (Nedry) chest. He (Nedry) looked down and saw a dripping glob of foam on his (Nedry) rain-soaked shirt. He (Nedry) touched it curiously, not comprehending... . It was spit. The dinosaur had spit on him (Nedry). It was creepy, he (Nedry) thought. He (Nedry) looked back at the di nosaur and saw the head snap again, and immediately felt another wet smack against his (Nedry) neck , just above the shirt collar. He (Nedry) wiped it away with his (Nedry) hand. Jesus, it was disgusting. But the skin of his (Jesus) neck was already starting to tingle and burn. And his (Jesus) hand was tingling, too. It was almost like he (Jesus) h ad been touched with acid. Nedry opened the car door, glancing back at the din osaur to make sure it wasn't going to attack, and felt a sudden, excruciating pain in his (Nedry) eyes, stabbing like spikes into the back of his (Nedry) skull, and he (Nedry) squeezed his (Nedry) eyes shut and gasped wit h the intensity of it and threw up his (Nedry) hands to cover his (Nedry) eyes and felt the slippery foam trickl ing down both sides of his (Nedry) nose. Spit. The dinosaur had spit in his (Nedry) eyes. Even as he (Nedry) realized it, the pain overwhelmed him (Nedry), a nd he (Nedry) dropped to his (Nedry) knees, disoriented, wheezing. He (Nedry) collapsed onto his (Nedry) side, his (Nedry) cheek pre ssed to the wet ground, his (Nedry) breath coming in thin whistles through the constant, ever-screaming pain that caused flashing spots of light to appear behind his (Nedry) tightly shut eyelids. The earth shook beneath him (Nedry) and Nedry knew the dino saur was moving, he (Nedry) could hear its soft hooting cry, and despite the pain he (Nedry) forced his (Nedry) eye s open and still he (Nedry) saw nothing but flashing spots against black. Slowly the realization came to him (Nedry). He (Nedry) was blind. The hooting was louder as Nedry scrambled to his (Nedry) fe et and staggered back against the side panel of the car, as a wave of nausea and dizziness swept over him (Nedry). The dinosaur was close now, he (Nedry) could feel it coming close, he (Nedry) was dimly aw are of its snorting breath. But he (Nedry) couldn't see. He (Nedry) couldn't see anything, and his (Nedry) terror was extrem e. He (Nedry) stretched out his (Nedry) hands, waving them wildly in t he (Nedry) air to ward off the attack he (Nedry) knew was coming. And then there was a new, searing pain, like a fier y knife in his (Nedry) belly, and Nedry stumbled, reaching blindly down to touch the ragged edge of h is shirt, and then a thick, slippery mass that was surprisingly warm, and with horror he (Nedry) suddenly knew he (Nedry) was holding his (Nedry) own intestines in his (Nedry) hands. The dinosaur had torn him (Nedry) open. His (Nedry) guts had fallen out. Nedry fell to the ground and landed on something sc aly and cold, it was the animal's foot, and then there was new pain on both sides of his (Nedry) head. The pain grew worse, and as he (Nedry) was lifted to his (Nedry) feet he (Nedry) knew the dinosaur had his (Nedry) head in its j aws, and the horror of that realization was followed by a final wish, that it would all be ende d soon. Bungalow

``More coffee?'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond asked politely.
``No, thank you,'' (Wu/Henry/Henry Wu)
Henry Wu said, leaning back in his (Wu) chair.
``I couldn't eat anything more.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
They were sitting in the dining room of Hammond's bungal ow, in a secluded corner of the park not far from the labs. Wu had to admit that the bungalow Ha mmond had built for himself was elegant, with sparse, almost Japanese lines. And the dinner had been excellent, considering the dining room wasn't fully staffed yet. But there was something about Hammond that Wu found troubling. The old man was different in some way ... subtly different. All during dinner, Wu had tried to decide what it was. In part, a tendency to ramble, to repeat himself, to retell ol d stories. In part, it was an emotional lability, flaring anger one moment, maudlin sentimentality th e next. But all that could be understood as a natural concomitant of age. John Hammond was, after all, almost seventy-seven. But there was something else. A stubborn evasivenes s. An insistence on having his (Hammond) way. And, in the end, a complete refusal to deal with the situat ion that now faced the park. Wu had been stunned by the evidence -LRB-he (Wu) did not yet allow himself to believe the case was proved-RRB- that the dinosaurs were breeding. After Gra nt had asked about amphibian DNA, Wu had intended to go directly to his (Wu) laboratory and check the computer records of the various DNA assemblies. Because, if the dinosaurs were in fact breeding, then everything about Jurassic Park was called into question-their genetic development methods, their genetic control methods, everything. Even the lysine dependency might be sus pect. And if these animals could truly breed, and could also survive in the wild ... Henry Wu wanted to check the data at once. But Hamm ond had stubbornly insisted Wu accompany him (Wu) at dinner.
``Now then, Henry, you must save room for ice cream, '' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond said, pushing back from the table.
``Maria makes the most wonderful ginger ice c ream.'' (unknown)
``All right.'' (Wu/Henry/Henry Wu)

Wu said.

Hammond glanced over.
``Must be the storm.'' (He)
He (Wu) reached behind him (Wu) for the telephone.
``I'll just check with John in control.'' (Wu/Henry/Henry Wu)
Wu could hear the static crackle on the telephone l ine. Hammond shrugged, and set the receiver back in its cradle.
``Lines must be down,'' (he)
he (Hammond) said.
``Or maybe Nedry's still doing data transmission. He (Nedry) has quite a few bugs to fix this w eekend. Nedry's a genius in his (Nedry) way, but we had to press him (Nedry) quite hard, toward the end, to mak e sure he (Nedry) got things right.'' (unknown)

Wu said.

Hammond said. He (Wu) tasted the ice cream.

Inwardly, Wu felt relieved. Perhaps the old man was going to face the facts, after all.

Their little faces will shine with t he (Henry) joy of finally seeing these wonderful animals. But I am afraid ... I may not live to see it, Henry. I may not live to see the joy on their faces.'' (unknown)

``that I may not live to see their shining, delighted faces. This is our triumph, this park. We have done what we set out to do. And, you remember, our original intent was to use the ne wly emerging technology of genetic engineering to make money. A lot of money.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Wu knew Hammond was about to launch into one of his (Hammond) old speeches. He (Hammond) held up his (Hammond) hand.
``I'm familiar with this, John-'' (unknown)
``If you were going to start a bioengineering compan y, Henry, what would you do? Would you make products to help mankind, to fight illness and disease? Dear me, no. That's a terrible idea. A very poor use of new technology.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond shook his (Hammond) head sadly.
``Yet, you'll remember ,'' (he)
he (Hammond) said,
``the original genetic engineering companies, like Genentech and Cetus, we re all started to make pharmaceuticals. New drugs for mankind. Noble, noble purpose. Unfort unately, drugs face all kinds of barriers. FDA testing alone takes five to eight years-if you' re lucky. Even worse, there are forces at work in the marketplace. Suppose you make a miracle drug fo r cancer or heart disease-as Genentech did. Suppose you now want to charge a thousand doll ars or two thousand dollars a dose. You might imagine that is your privilege. After all, yo u invented the drug, you paid to develop and test it; you should be able to charge whatever you wish. But do you really think that the government will let you do that? No, Henry, they will not. Sic k people aren't going to pay a thousand dollars a dose for needed medication-they won't be grateful, they'll be outraged. Blue Cross isn't going to pay it. They'll scream highway robbery. So somethin g will happen. Your patent application will be denied. Your permits will be delayed. Something wil l force you to see reason-and to sell your drug at a lower cost. From a business standpoint, t hat makes helping mankind a very risky business. Personally, I would never help mankind.'' (he)
Wu had heard the argument before. And he (Wu) knew Hammo nd was right, some new bioengineered pharmaceuticals had indeed suffered i nexplicable delays and patent problems.
``Now,'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond said,
``think how different it is whe n you're making entertainment, Nobody needs entertainment. That's not a matter for govern ment intervention. If I charge five thousand dollars a day for my park, who is going to stop me? After all, nobody needs to come here. And, far from being highway robbery, a costly price tag actually increases the appeal of the park. A visit becomes a status symbol, and all Americans lo ve that. So do the Japanese, and of course they have far more money.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)

Hammond smiled.

Construction on the next two Jurassic Parks will be gin early next year. They will all be open within four years. At that time, direct revenues wi ll exceed ten billion dollars a year, and merchandising, television, and ancillary rights sho uld double that. I see no reason to bother with children's pets, which I'm told Lew Dodgson thinks we're planning to make.'' (unknown)

``Jesus,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. The Jeep screeched to a stop.
``Sorry,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said . In the headlamps, Ellie saw a herd of apatosaurs lu mbering across the road. There were six animals, each the size of a house, and a baby as la rge as a full-grown horse. The apatosaurs moved in unhurried silence, never looking toward th e Jeep and its glowing headlamps. At one point, the baby stopped to lap water from a puddle in the road, then moved on. A comparable herd of elephants would have been star tled by the arrival of a car, would have trumpeted and circled to protect the baby. But thes e animals showed no fear.
``Don't they see us?'' (she)
she (baby) said.
``Not exactly, no,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said. ``Of course, in a l iteral sense they do see us, but we don't really mean anything to them. We hardly ever take cars out at night, and so they have no experience of them. We are just a strange, smelly object in their environment. Representing no threat, and therefore no interest. I've occasionally been out a t night, visiting a sick animal, and on my way back these fellows blocked the road for an hour or more. ``What do you do?'' Harding grinned. ``Play a recorded tyrannosaur roar. That gets them moving. Not that they care much about tyrannosaurs. These apatosaurs are so bi g they don't really have any predators. They can break a tyrannosaur's neck with a swipe of their tail. And they know it. So does the tyrannosaur.'' ``But they do see us. I mean, if we were to get out of the car ...'' Harding shrugged. ``They probably wouldn't react. Di nosaurs have excellent visual acuity, but they have a basic amphibian visual system: it's att uned to movement. They don't see unmoving things well at all.'' The animals moved on, their skin glistening in the rain. Harding put the car in gear. ``I think we can continue now,'' he (Harding) said. Wu said, ``I suspect you may find there are pressure s on your park, just as there are pressures on Genentech's drugs.'' He (Wu) and Hammond had moved to the living room, and they were now watching the storm lash the big glass windows. ``I can't see how,'' Hammond said. ``The scientists may wish to constrain you. Even to stop you.
``Well, they can't do that, '' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond said. He (Hammond) shook his (Hammond) finger at Wu.
``You know why the scientists would try to do that? It's because they want to do research, of course. That's all they ever want to do, is research. Not to accomplish any thing. Not to make any progress. Just do research. Well, they have a surprise coming to them .'' (unknown)
``I wasn't thinking of that,'' (Wu/Henry/Henry Wu)
Wu said. Hammond sighed.
``I'm sure it would be interesting f or the scientists, to do research. But you arrive at the point where these animals are simply too expensive to be used for research. This is wonderful technology, Henry, but it's also frightfu lly expensive technology. The fact is, it can only be supported as entertainment.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond shrugged.
'' That's just the way it is.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
``But if there are attempts to close down-'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
``Face the damn facts, Henry,'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond said irritabl y.
``This isn't America. This isn't even Costa Rica. This is my island. I own it. And nothin g is going to stop me from opening Jurassic Park to all the children of the world.'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
He (Hammond) chuckled .
``Or, at least, to the rich ones. And I tell you, they'll love it.'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
In the back seat of the Jeep, Ellie Sattler stared out the window. They had been driving through rain-drenched jungle for the last twenty minutes, a nd had seen nothing since the apatosaurs crossed the road.
``We're near the jungle river now,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said, as he (Harding) drove.
``It's off there somewhere to our left.'' (he)
Abruptly he (Harding) slammed on the brakes again, The car sk idded to a stop in front of a flock of small green animals.
``Well, you're getting quite a show t onight,'' (he)
he (Harding) said.
``Those are compys.'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Procompsognathids, Ellie thought, wishing that Gran t were here to see them. This was the animal they had seen in the fax, back in Montana. T he (Harding) little dark green procompsognathids scurried to the other side of the road, then squatt ed on their hind legs to look at the car, chattering briefly, before hurrying onward into the night.
``Odd,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said.
``Wonder where they're off to? Compys don't usually move at night, you know. They climb up in a tree and wait for daylight .'' (unknown)
``Then why are they out now?'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Ellie said.
``I can't imagine. You know compys are scavengers, l ike buzzards. They're attracted to a dying animal, and they have tremendously sensitive smell. They can smell a dying animal for miles.'' (unknown)
``Then they're going to a dying animal?'' (unknown)
``Dying, or already dead.'' (unknown)
``Should we follow them?'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Ellie said.
``I'd be curious,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said. ``Yes, why not? Let' s go see where they're going. He (they) turned the car around, and headed back toward the c ompys. Tim Tim Murphy lay in the Land Cruiser, his (Murphy) cheek press ed against the car door handle. He (Murphy) drifted slowly back to consciousness. He (Murphy) wanted only to sle ep. He (Murphy) shifted his (Murphy) position, and felt the pain in his (Murphy) cheekbone where it lay against the metal doo r. His (Murphy) whole body ached. His (Murphy) arms and his (Murphy) legs and most of all his (Murphy) head-there was a terrible pounding pain in his (Murphy) head. All the pain made him (Murphy) want to go back to sleep. He (Murphy) pushed himself up on one elbow, opened his (Murphy) eyes, and retched, vomiting all over his (Murphy) shirt. He (Murphy) tasted sour bile and wiped his (Murphy) mouth with the ba ck of his (Murphy) hand. His (Murphy) head throbbed; he (Murphy) felt dizzy and seasick, as if the world were moving, as if he (Murphy) were rocking back and forth on a boat. Tim groaned, and rolled onto his (Tim) back, turning away from the puddle of vomit. The pain in his (Tim) head made him (Tim) breathe in short, shallow gasps. And he (Tim) still felt sick, as if everything were moving. He (Tim) opened his (Tim) eyes and looked around, tryin g to get his (Tim) bearings. He (Tim) was inside the Land Cruiser. But the car must ha ve flipped over on its side, because he (Tim) was lying on his (Tim) back against the passenger door, l ooking up at the steering wheel and beyond, at the branches of a tree, moving in the wind. The rai n had nearly stopped, but water drops still fell on him (Tim) through the broken front windshield. He (Tim) stared curiously at the fragments of glass. He (Tim) c ouldn't remember how the windshield had broken. He (Tim) couldn't remember anything except that t hey had been parked on the road and he (Tim) had been talking to Dr. Grant when the tyrannosaur came toward them. That was the last thing he (Grant) remembered. He (Grant) felt sick again, and closed his (Grant) eyes until the n ausea passed. He (Grant) was aware of a rhythmic creaking sound, like the rigging of a boat. Dizzy a nd sick to his (Grant) stomach, he (Grant) really felt as if the whole car were moving beneath him (Grant). But when he (Grant) open ed his (Grant) eyes again, he (Grant) saw it was true-the Land Cruiser was moving, lying on its side, swaying back and forth. The whole car was moving. Tentatively, Tim rose to his (Tim) feet. Standing on the passenger door, he (Tim) peered over the dashboard, looking out through the shattered windsh ield. At first he (Tim) saw only dense foliage, moving in the wind. But here and there he (Tim) could see gaps, and beyond the foliage, the ground was- The ground was twenty feet below him (Tim). He (Tim) stared uncomprehendingly. The Land Cruiser was l ying on its side in the branches of a large tree, twenty feet above the ground, swaying b ack and forth in the wind. ``Oh shit,'' he (Harding) said. What was he (Harding) going to do? He (Harding) sto od on his (Harding) tiptoes and peered out, trying to see better, grabbing the steering wheel for support . The wheel spun free in his (Harding) hand, and with a loud crack the Land Cruiser shifted position, dropp ing a few feet in the branches of the tree. He (Harding) looked down through the shattered glass of the pass enger-door window at the ground below. ``Oh shit. Oh shit.'' He (Harding) kept repeating it.
``Oh shit. Oh shit.'' (unknown)
Another loud crack-the Land Cruiser jolted down ano ther foot. He (Harding) had to get out of here. He (Harding) looked down at his (Harding) feet. He (Harding) was standing on the door handle. He (Harding) crouched back down on his (Harding) bands and knees to look at the handle. He (Harding) could n't see very well in the dark, but he (Harding) could tell that the door was dented outward so the handle coul dn't turn. He (Harding)'d never get the door open. He (Harding) tried to roll the window down, but the window was s tuck, too. Then he (Harding) thought of the back door. Maybe he (Harding) could open that. He (Harding) leaned over the front seat, and the Land Cruiser lurched with the shift in weight. Carefully, Tim reached back and twisted the handle on the rear door. It was stuck, too. How was he (Tim) going to get out? He (Tim) heard a snorting sound and looked down. A dark s hape passed below him (Tim). It wasn't the tyrannosaur. This shape was tubby and it made a kin d of snuffling as it waddled along. The tail flopped back and forth, and Tim could see the long spikes. It was the stegosaur, apparently recovered from its illness. Tim wondered where the other people were: Gennaro and Sattler and the vet. He (Gennaro) ha d last seen them near the stegosaur. How long ago was that? He (Gennaro) looked at his (Gennaro) watch, but the face was cracked; he (Gennaro) couldn't see the numbers. He (Gennaro) took the watch off and tossed it aside.

The stegosaur snuffled and moved on. Now the only s ound was the wind in the trees, and the creaking of the Land Cruiser as it shifted back and forth. He (Gennaro) had to get out of here. Tim grabbed the handle, tried to force it, but it w as stuck solid. It wouldn't move at all. Then he (Tim) realized what was wrong: the rear door was locked! Tim pulled up the pin and twisted the handle. The rear door swung open, downward-and came to rest against the branch a few feet below. The opening was narrow, but Tim thought he (Tim) could wr iggle through it. Holding his (Tim) breath, he (Tim) crawled slowly back into the rear seat. The Land Cr uiser creaked, but held its position. Gripping the doorposts on both sides, Tim slowly lowered him (Tim) self down, through the narrow angled opening of the door. Soon he (Tim) was lying flat on his (Tim) stomach on the slanted door, his (Tim) legs sticking out of the car. He (Tim) kicked in the air-his feet touch ed something solid-a branch-and he (Tim) rested his (Tim) weight on it. As soon as he (Tim) did, the branch bent down and the doo r swung wider, spilling him (Tim) out of the Land Cruiser, and he (Tim) fell-leaves scratching his (Tim) fac e-his body bouncing from branch to branch-a jolt-searing pain, bright light in his (Tim) head- He (Tim) slammed to a stop, the wind knocked from him (Tim). Ti m lay doubled over a large branch, his (Tim) stomach burning pain. Tim heard another crack and looked up at the Land C ruiser, a big dark shape five feet above him (Tim). Another crack. The car shifted. Tim forced himself to move, to climb down. He (Tim) used to like to climb trees. He (Tim) was a good tree- climber. And this was a good tree to climb, the bra nches spaced close together, almost like a staircase... . Crackkkk ... The car was definitely moving. Tim scrambled downward, slipping over the wet branc hes, feeling sticky sap on his (Tim) hands, hurrying. He (Tim) had not descended more than a few feet when the Land Cruiser creaked a final time, and then slowly, very slowly, nosed over. Tim could see the big green grille and the front headlights swinging down at him (Tim), and then the Land Cruiser fell free, gaining momentum as it rushed toward him (Tim), slamming against the branch wher e Tim had just been- And it stopped. His (Tim) face just inches from the dented grille, bent i nward like an evil mouth, headlamps for eyes. Oil dripped on Tim's face. He (Tim) was still twelve feet above the ground. He (Tim) reach ed down, found another branch, and moved down. Above, he (Tim) saw the branch bending under the weight of the Land Cruiser, and then it cracked, and the Land Cruiser came rushing down toward him (Tim) and he (Tim) knew he (Tim) could never escape it, he (Tim) could never get down fast enough, so Tim just let go. He (Tim) fell the rest of the way. Tumbling, banging, feeling pain in every part of hi s body, hearing the Land Cruiser smashing down through the branches after him (Tim) like a pursuing animal, and then Tim's shoulder hit the soft ground, and he (Tim) rolled as hard as he (Tim) could, and pres sed his (Tim) body against the trunk of the tree as the Land Cruiser tumbled down with a loud metallic crash and a sudden hot burst of electrical sparks that stung his (Tim) skin and sputtered and sizzle d on the wet ground around him (Tim). Slowly, Tim got to his (Tim) feet. In the darkness he (Tim) hea rd the snuffling, and saw the stegosaur coming back, apparently attracted by the crash of the Land Cruiser. The dinosaur moved dumbly, the low head thrust forward, and the big cartilaginous plat es running in two rows along the bump of the back. It behaved like an overgrown tortoise. Stupid like that. And slow. Tim picked up a rock and threw it.

``Get away!'' (unknown)
The rock tbunked dully off the plates. The stegosau r kept coming.
``Go on! Co!'' (He)
He (Tim) threw another rock, and hit the stegosaur in the head. The animal grunted, turned slowly away, and shuffled off in the direction it had come . Tim leaned against the crumpled Land Cruiser and lo oked around in the darkness. He (Tim) had to get back to the others, but he (Tim) didn't want to get l ost. He (Tim) knew he (Tim) was somewhere in the park, probably not far from the main road. If he (Tim) could on ly get his (Tim) hearings. He (Tim) couldn't see much in the dark, but- Then he (Tim) remembered the goggles. He (Tim) climbed through the shattered front windshield i nto the Land Cruiser and found the night- vision goggles, and the radio. The radio was broken and silent, so he (Tim) left it behind. But the goggles still worked. He (Tim) flicked them on, saw the r eassuringly familiar phosphorescent green image. Wearing the goggles, he (Tim) saw the battered fence off to his (Tim) left, and walked toward it. The fence was twelve feet high, but the tyrannosaur had flatt ened it easily. Tim hurried across it, moved through an area of dense foliage, and came out onto the main road. Through his (Tim) goggles, he (Tim) saw the other Land Cruiser turned on its side. He (Tim) ran toward it, took a breath, and looked inside. The car was empty. No si gn of Dr. Grant and Dr. Malcolm. Where had they gone? Where had everybody gone? He (Malcolm) felt sudden panic, standing alone in the jungle road at night with that empty car, and turned quickly in circles, seeing the bright green world i n the goggles swirl. Something pale by the side of the road caught his (Malcolm) eye. It was Lex's baseball. He (Malcolm) wiped the mud off it.
``Lex!'' (Tim)
Tim shouted as loud as he (Tim) could, not caring if the animals heard him (Tim). He (Tim) listened, but there was only the wind, and the plink of raindrops falli ng from the trees. '' Lex! He (Lex) vaguely remembered that she (Malcolm) had been in the Land Cruiser when the tyrannosaur attacked. Had she (Malcolm) stayed there? Or had she (Malcolm) gotten a way? The events of the attack were confused in his (Lex) mind. He (Lex) wasn't exactly sure what h ad happened, just to think of it made him (Lex) uneasy. He (Lex) stood in the road, gasping with panic. ``Lex!'' The night seemed to close in around him (Lex). Feeling so rry for himself, he (Lex) sat in a cold rainy puddle in the road and whimpered for a while. When he (Lex) finally stopped, he (Lex) still heard whimpering. Henry Wu opened the door marked FERTILIZATION and e ntered the darkened lab. There was nobody here; apparently all the technicians were st ill at dinner. Wu went directly to the computer terminal and punched up the DNA logbooks. The logbo oks had to be kept on computer. DNA was such a large molecule that each species required te n gigabytes of optical disk space to store details of all the iterations. He (Wu) was going to have to check all fifteen species. That was a tremendous amount of information to search through.

He (Wu) still wasn't clear about why Grant thought frog DNA was important. Wu himself didn't often distinguish one kind of DNA from another. After all , most DNA in living creatures was exactly the same. DNA was an incredibly ancient substance. Huma n beings, walking around in the streets of the modern world, bouncing their pink new babies, h ardly stopped to think that the substance at the center of it all-the substance that began the d ance of life-was a chemical almost as old as the earth itself. The DNA molecule was so old that its evolution had essentially finished more than two billion years ago. There had been little new si nce that time. Just a few recent combinations of the old genes-and not much of that. When you compared the DNA of man and the DNA of a l owly bacterium, you found that only about 10 percent of the strands were different. Thi s innate conservatism of DNA emboldened Wu to use whatever DNA he (Wu) wished. In making his (Wu) dinosa urs, Wu had manipulated the DNA as a sculptor might clay or marble. He (Wu) had created freel y. He (Wu) started the computer search program, knowing it would take two or three minutes to run. He (Wu) got up and walked around the lab, checking instr uments out of long-standing habit. He (Wu) noted the recorder outside the freezer door, which tracke d the freezer temperature. He (Wu) saw there was a spike in the graph. That was odd, he (Wu) thought. It me ant somebody had been in the freezer. Recently, too-witbin the last half-hour. But who wo uld go in there at night? The computer beeped, signaling that the first of th e data searches was complete. Wu went over to see what it had found, and when he (Wu) saw the screen, he (Wu) forgot all about the freezer and the graph spike. LEITZKE DNA SEARCH ALGORITHM DNA: Version Search Criteria: RANA -LRB-all, fragment l en > 0-RRB- DNA Incorporating RANA Fragments Maiasaurs Procompsognathids Othnielia Velociraptors Hypsilopbodontids Versions 2.1-2.9

3.0-3.7

3.1-3.3

1.0-3.0

2.4-2.7 The result was clear: all breeding dinosaurs incorp orated rana, or frog, DNA. None of the other animals did. Wu still did not understand why this h ad caused them to breed. But he (Wu) could no longer deny that Grant was right. The dinosaurs wer e breeding. He (Grant) hurried up to the control room. Shivering, Ed Regis got to his (Regis) feet, and wiped the cold mud off his (Regis) face and hands. He (Regis) had spent a very had half hour, wedged among big boulders on th e slope of a hill below the road. He (Regis) knew it wasn't much of a hiding place, but he (Regis) was panicked and he (Regis) wasn't thinking clearly. He (Regis) had lain in this muddy cold place and he (Regis) had tried to get hold of himself, but he (Regis) kept seeing that dinosaur in his (Regis) mind. That dinosaur coming toward him (Regis). Toward t he (Regis) car. Ed Regis didn't remember exactly what had happened after that. He (Regis) remembered that Lex had said something but he (Lex) hadn't stopped, he (Lex) couldn't s top, he (Lex) had just kept running and running. Beyond the road he (Lex) had lost his (Lex) footing and tumbled down the hill and come to rest by some boulders, and it had seemed to him (Lex) that he (Lex) could cr awl in among the boulders, and hide, there was enough room, so that was what he (Lex) had done. Gasp ing and terrified, thinking of nothing except to get away from the tyrannosaur. And, final ly, when he (Lex) was wedged in there like a rat between the boulders, he (Lex) had calmed down a little, and he (Lex) had been overcome with horror and shame because he (Lex)'d abandoned those kids, he (Lex) had jus t run away, he (Lex) had just saved himself. He (Lex) knew he (Lex) should go back up to the road, he (Lex) should tr y to rescue them, because he (Lex) had always imagined himself as brave and cool under pressure, but whenever he (Lex) tried to get control of himself, to make himself go back up there-somehow h e just couldn't. He (Lex) started to feel panicky, and he (Lex) had trouble breathing, and he (Lex) didn't move. He (Lex) told himself it was hopeless, anyway. If the kid s were still up there on the road they could never survive, and certainly there was nothing Ed R egis could do for them, and he (Ed) might as well stay where he (Ed) was. No one was going to know what ha d happened except him (Ed). And there was nothing he (Ed) could do. Nothing he (Ed) could have done. An d so Regis had remained among the boulders for half an hour, fighting off panic, care fully not thinking about whether the kids had died,

or about what Hammond would have to say when he (Hammond) fou nd out. What finally made him (Hammond) move was the peculiar sensati on he (Hammond) noticed in his (Hammond) mouth. The side of his (Hammond) mouth felt funny, kind of numb and tingling, an d he (Hammond) wondered if he (Hammond) had hurt it during the fall. Regis touched his (Regis) face and felt swollen flesh on th e side of his (Regis) mouth. It was funny, but it didn't hurt at all. Then he (Regis) realized the swollen flesh was a leech growing fat as it sucked his (Regis) lips. It was practically in his (Regis) mouth. Shivering with nausea, Re gis pulled the leech away, feeling it tear from the flesh of his (Regis) lips, feeling the gush of warm blo od in his (Regis) mouth. He (Regis) spat, and flung it with disgust

into the forest. He (Regis) saw another leech on his (Regis) forear m, and pulled it off, leaving a dark bloody streak behind. Jesus, he (Jesus) was probably covered with them. That fall down the hillside. These jungle hills were full of leeches. So were the dark rocky crevices. What did the workmen say? The leeches crawled up your underwear. They liked d ark warm places. They liked to crawl right up your-

``Hellooo!'' (He)
He (Jesus) stopped. It was a voice, carried by the wind.
``Helloo! Dr. Grant!'' (Jesus/Christ/Jesus Christ)
Jesus, that was the little girl. Ed Regis listened to the tone of her (girl) voice. She (girl) did n't sound frightened, or in pain. She (girl) was just calling in her (girl) insistent way. And it slowly dawned on him (Regis) that something else must have happened, that the tyrannosaur must have gone away- or at least hadn't attacked-and that the other people might still be alive. Grant and Malcol m. Everybody might be alive. An the realization made him (Grant) pull himself together in an instant, the w ay you got sober in an instant when the cops pulled you over, and he (Grant) felt better, because now he (Grant) knew what he (Grant) had to do. And as he (Grant) crawled out from the boulders he (Grant) was already formulating th e next step, already figuring out what he (Grant) would say, how to handle things from this point. Regis wiped the cold mud off his (Regis) face and hands, th e evidence that he (Regis) had been hiding. He (Regis) wasn't embarrassed that he (Regis) had been hiding, but now he (Regis) had to take charge. He (Regis) scrambled back up toward the road, but when he (Regis) emerged from the fo liage he (Regis) had a moment of disorientation. He (Regis) didn't see the cars at all. He (Regis) was somehow at the b ottom of the hill. The Land Cruisers must be at the top. He (Regis) started walking up the hill, back toward the Lan d Cruisers. It was very quiet. His (Regis) feet splashed in the muddy puddles. He (Regis) couldn't bear the little girl any more. Why had she (girl) stopped calling? As he (Regis) walked, he (Regis) began to think that maybe something had happened to her (girl). In that case, he (Regis) shouldn't walk back there. Maybe the tyran nosaur was still hanging around. Here he (Regis) was, already at the bottom of the hill. That much c loser to home. And it was so quiet. Spooky, it was so quiet. Ed Regis turned around, and started walking back to ward the camp. Alan Grant ran his (Grant) hands over her (girl) limbs, squeezing the arms and legs briefly. She (girl) didn't seem to have any pain. It was amazing: aside from a cut on her (girl) head, she (girl) was fine.
``I told you I was,'' (she)
she (girl) said.
``Well, I had to check.'' (The boy)
The boy was not quite so fortunate. Tim's nose was swollen and painful; Grant suspected it was broken. His (Grant) right shoulder was badly bruised an d swollen. But his (Grant) legs seemed to be all right. Both kids could walk. That was the important thing. Grant himself was all right except for a claw abras ion down his (Grant) right chest, where the tyrannosaur had kicked him (Grant). It burned with every br eath, but it didn't seem to be serious, and it didn't limit his (Grant) movement. He (Grant) wondered if he (Grant) had been knocked unconscious, bec ause he (Grant) had only dim recollections of events immediately preceding the moment he (Grant) had sat up, groaning, in the woods ten yards from the Land Cruiser. At first his (Grant) chest had been bleed ing, so he (Grant) had stuck leaves on the wound, and after a while it clotted. Then he (Grant) had started walki ng around, looking for Malcolm and the kids. Grant couldn't believe he (Grant) was still alive, and as s cattered images began to come back to him (Grant), he (Grant) tried to make sense of them. The tyrannosaur should have killed them all easily. Why hadn't it?
``I'm hungry,'' (Lex)

``We're the only ones who know?'' (Tim)
Tim said. ``Yes.

We've got to get back and tell them.'' ``Then let's walk down the road toward the hotel,'' T im said, pointing down the hill. ``That way we'll meet them when they come for us.'' Grant considered that. And he (Grant) kept thinking about o ne thing: the dark shape that had crossed between the Land Cruisers even before the attack st arted. What animal had that been? He (Grant) could think of only one possibility-the little tyrannosau r. ``I don't think so, Tim. Tim said. ``Yes,'' Grant said. ``Let's just wait here until some one comes.'' ``I'm hungry,'' Lex said. ``I hope it won't be very long,'' Grant said. ``I

don't want to stay here,'' Lex said. Then, from the bottom of the hill, they heard the s ound of a man coughing. ``Stay here,'' Grant said. He (Grant) ran forward, to look do wn the hill. ``Stay here,'' Tim said, and he (Tim) ran forward after him (Tim). Lex followed her (Tim) brother. ``Don't leave me, don't le ave me here, you guys-'' Grant clapped his (Grant) band over her (Tim) mouth. She (Tim) struggle d to protest. He (Grant) shook his (Grant) head, and pointed over the hill, for her (Tim) to look. At the bottom of the hill, Grant saw Ed Regis, stan ding rigid, unmoving. The forest around them had become deadly silent. The steady background dro ne of cicadas and frogs had ceased abruptly. There was only the faint rustle of leaves , and the whine of the wind, Lex started to speak, but Grant pulled her (Tim) against the trunk of the nearest tree, ducking down among the heavy gnarled roots at the base. Tim came in right after them. Grant put his (Grant) hands to his (Grant) lips, signaling them to be quiet, and then he (Grant) s lowly looked around the tree. The road below was dark, and as the branches of the big trees moved in the wind, the moonlight filtering through made a dappled, shiftin g pattern. Ed Regis was gone. It took Grant a moment to locate him (Grant). The publicist was pressed up against the trunk of a big tree, hugging it. Regis wasn't moving at all. The forest remained silent. Lex tugged impatiently at Grant's shirt; she (publicist) wanted to know what was happening. Then, from somewhere very near, they heard a soft snorting exh alation, hardly louder than the wind. Lex heard it, too, because she (publicist) stopped struggling. The sound floated toward them again, soft as a sigh . Grant thought it was almost like the breathing of a horse. Grant looked at Regis, and saw the moving shadows c ast by the moonlight on the trunk of the tree. And then Grant realized there was another sha dow, superimposed on the others, but not moving: a strong curved neck, and a square head. The exhalation came again. Tim leaned forward cautiously, to look. Lex did, to o. They heard a crack as a branch broke, and into the path stepped a tyrannosaur. It was the juvenile: about eight feet tall, and it moved with the clumsy gait of a young animal, almost like a puppy. The juvenile tyrannosaur shuffled down the p ath, stopping with every step to sniff the air before moving on. It passed the tree where Regis wa s hiding, and gave no indication that it had seen him (Lex). Grant saw Regis's body relax slightly. Re gis turned his (Grant) head, trying to watch the tyrannosaur on the far side of the tree. The tyrannosaur was now out of view down the road. Regis started to relax, releasing his (Regis) grip on the tree. But the jungle remained silent. Regis remained close to the tree trunk for another half a minute. Then the sounds of the forest returned: t he (Regis) first tentative croak of a tree frog, the buzz of one cicada, and then the full chorus. Regis step ped away from the tree, shaking his (Regis) shoulders, releasing the tension. He (Regis) walked into the middle of the road, looking in the direction of the departed tyrannosaur. The attack came from the left. The juvenile roared as it swung its head forward, k nocking Regis flat to the ground. He (Regis) yelled and scrambled to his (Regis) feet, but the tyrannosaur poun ced, and it must have pinned him (Regis) with its hind leg, because suddenly Regis wasn't moving, he (Regis) was s itting up in the path shouting at the dinosaur and waving his (Regis) hands at it, as if he (Regis) could scare it off. The young dinosaur seemed perplexed by the sounds and movement coming from it s tiny prey. The juvenile bent its head over, sniffing curiously, and Regis pounded on the snout with his (Regis) fists. ``Get away! Back off! Go on, back off!'' Regis was sh outing at the top of his (Regis) lungs, and the dinosaur backed away, allowing Regis to get to his (Regis) feet. Regis was shouting ``Yeah! You heard me! Back off! Get away!'' as he (Regis) moved away from the dinosaur. The juvenile continued to stare curiously at the odd, noisy little animal before it , but when Regis had gone a few paces, it lunged and knocked him (Regis) down again. It's playing with him (Regis), Grant thought. ``Hey!'' Regis shouted as he (Regis) fell, but the juvenile d id not pursue him (Regis), allowing him (Regis) to get to his (Regis) feet. He (Regis) jumped to his (Regis) feet, and continued backing away. ``You stupid-back! Back! You heard me- back!'' he (Regis) shouted like a lion tamer. The juvenile roared, but it did not attack, and Reg is now edged toward the trees and high foliage to the right. In another few steps he (Reg) would be in hiding. ``Back! You! Back!'' Regis shouted, and then, at the last moment the juvenile pounced, and knocked Regis flat on his (Regis) back. ``Cut that out'', Regis yelled, and the juvenile ducked his (Regis) hea d, and Regis began to scream. No words, just a high-pitched scream. The scream cut off abruptly, and when the juvenile lifted his (Regis) head, Grant saw ragged flesh in his (Grant) jaws. ``Oh no,'' Lex said, softly. Beside her (Regis), Tim had turn ed away, suddenly nauseated. His (Tim) night- vision goggles slipped from his (Tim) forehead and landed on the ground with a metallic clink. The juvenile's head snapped up, and it looked towar d the top of the hill. Tim picked up his (Tim) goggles as Grant grabbed both the children's hands and began to run. Control In the night, the compys scurried along the side of the road. Harding's Jeep followed a short distance behind. Ellie pointed farther up the road. ``Is that a light?'' ``Could be,'' Harding said. ``Looks almost like headli ghts.

'' The radio suddenly bummed and crackled. They heard John Arnold say, '' (unknown)
-you there?'' ``Ah, there he (me) is,'' Harding said. ``Finally.'' He (Harding) pres sed the button. ``Yes, John, we're here. We're near the river, following the compys. It's quite in teresting.

-eed your car-''

Harding pressed the button.

``I just wish I understood what the urgency is.'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding put the Jeep in gear, and they rumbled down the road in the darkness. It was another ten minutes before they saw the welcoming lights of the Safari Lodge. And as Harding pulled to a stop in front of the visitor center, they saw Muldo on coming toward them. He (Harding) was shouting, and waving his (Harding) arms.
``God damn it, Arnold, you son of a bitch! God damn it, get this park back on track! Now! Get my grandkids back here! Now!'' (John/John Hammond)
John Hammond stood in th e control room, screaming and stamping his (Hammond) little feet. He (Hammond) had been carrying on this way f or the last two minutes, while Henry Wu stood in the corner, looking stunned.
``Well, Mr. Hammond,'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said,
``Muldoon's on his (Muldoon) way out right now, to do exactly that.'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold turned away, and lit another cigarette. Hamm ond was like every other management guy Arnold had ever seen. Whether it was Disney or the Navy, management guys always behaved the same. They never understood the technical issue s; and they thought that screaming was the way to make things happen. And maybe it was, if you were shouting at your secretaries to get you a limousine. But screaming didn't make any difference at all to the problems that Arnold now faced. The computer didn't care if it was screamed at. The pow er network didn't care if it was screamed at. Technical systems were completely indifferent to al l this explosive human emotion. If anything, screaming was counterproductive, because Arnold now faced the virtual certainty that Nedry wasn't coming back, which meant that Arnold himself had to go into the computer code and try and figure out what had gone wrong. It was going to be a painstaking job, he (Arnold)'d need to be calm and careful.
``Why don't you go downstairs to the cafeteria,'' (unknown)
Arn old said,
``and get a cup of coffee? We'll call you when we have more news.'' (unknown)

Hammond said.

``Don't worry about a Malcolm Effect,'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said.
``Will you let me go to work?'' (unknown)
``God damn you,'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Hammond said.
``I'll call you, sir, when I have news from Muldoon, '' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said. He (Arnold) pushed buttons on his (Arnold) console, and saw the famil iar control screens change. */Jurassic Park Main Modules/ */ */ Call Libs Include: biostat.sys

He (Arnold) had now gone behind the scenes to look at the code-the line-by-line instructions that told th e computer how to behave. Arnold was unhappily aware that the complete Jurassic Park program conta ined more than half a million lines of code, most of it undocumented, without explanation. Wu came forward.

The Road Muldoon took the curve very fast, the Jeep sliding on the mud. Sitting beside him (Arnold), Gennaro clenched his (Gennaro) fists. They were racing along the clif f road, high above the river, now hidden below them in darkness. Muldoon accelerated forward. His (Muldoon) face was tense.
``How much farther?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``Two, maybe three miles.'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Ellie and Harding were back at the visitor center. Gennaro had offered to accompany Muldoon. The car swerved.
``It's been an hour,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``An hour, with no word from the other cars.'' (unknown)
``But they have radios,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.

Muldoon said.

Gennaro frowned.

Muldoon said. Gennaro shook his (Gennaro) head.
``You really think something could have happened to them?'' (unknown)

Muldoon said,
``that they're perfectl y fine, but I'll he (them) happier when I finally see them. Should be any minute now.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
The road curved, and then ran up a hill. At the bas e of the hill Gennaro saw something white, lying among the ferns by the side of the road.
``Hol d it,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said, and Muldoon braked. Gennaro jumped out and ran forward in the headlight s of the Jeep to see what it was. It looked like a piece of clothing, but there was- Gennaro stopped. Even from six feet away, he (Gennaro) could see clearly what it was. He (Gennaro) walked forward more slowly. Muldoon leaned out of the car and said,
``What is it ?'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
``It's a leg,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said. The flesh of the leg was pale blue-wbite, terminati ng in a ragged bloody stump where the knee had been. Below the calf he (Gennaro) saw a white sock, and a brown slip-on shoe. It was the kind of sboe Ed Regis had been wearing. By then Muldoon was out of the car, running past hi m to crouch over the leg.
``Jesus.'' (He)
He (Muldoon) lifted the leg out of the foliage, raising it into the lig ht of the headlamps, and blood from the stump gushed down over his (Muldoon) band. Gennaro was still three feet away. He (Gennaro) quickly bent over, put his (Gennaro) hands on his (Gennaro) knees, squeezed his (Gennaro) eyes shut, and bre athed deeply, trying not to be sick.
``Gennaro.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon's voice was sharp.
``What?'' (unknown)
``Move. You're blocking the light.'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro took a breath, and moved. When he (Gennaro) opened hi s eyes he (Gennaro) saw Muldoon peering critically at the stump.
``Torn at the joint line,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said,
``Didn't bite it-twisted and ripped it . Just ripped his (Gennaro) leg off.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon stood up, holding the severed leg upside down so the remaining blood dripped onto the ferns. His (Muldoon) bloody hand smudg ed the white sock as fie gripped the ankle. Gennaro felt sick again.
``No question what happened,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon was saying.
``T he (Gennaro) T-rex got him (Gennaro).'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon looked up the hill, then back to Gennaro.
``You all right? Can you go on?'' (unknown)
``Yes,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``I can go on.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon was walking back toward the Jeep, carrying the leg.
``I guess we better bring this along,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said.
``Doesn't seem right to leave it he (Gennaro) re. Christ, it's going to make a mess of the car. See if there's anything in the back, will you? A ta rp or newspaper ...'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro opened the back door and rummaged around in the space behind the rear seat. He (Gennaro) felt grateful to think about something else for a m oment. The problem of how to wrap the severed leg expanded to fill his (Gennaro) mind, crowding out all oth er thoughts. He (Gennaro) found a canvas bag with a tool kit, a wheel rim, a cardboard box, and-
``Two tarps,'' (He)
he (Gennaro) said. They were neatly folded plast ic.

Muldoon said, still standing outside the car. Muldoon wrapped the leg and passed the now shapeless bundle to Gennaro. Holding it in his (Gennaro) hand, Gennaro was surprised at how heavy it felt.

Muldo on said.

Gennaro put the bundle in the back, and Mul doon got behind the wheel. He (Gennaro) accelerated, the wheels spinning in the mud, then d igging in. The Jeep rushed up the hill, and for a moment at the top the headlights still pointed up ward into the foliage, and then they swung down, and Gennaro could see the road before them.
``Jesus,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. Gennaro saw a single Land Cruiser, lying on its sid e in the center of the road. He (Gennaro) couldn't see the second Land Cruiser at all.
``Where's the other car?'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon looked around briefly, pointed to the left.
``There.'' (Land Cruiser/Cruiser)
The second Land Cruiser was twenty feet away, crumpled at the foot of a tree.
``What's it doing there?'' (unknown)
``The T-rex threw it.'' (unknown)
``Threw it?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said. Muldoon's face was grim.
``Let's get this over with, '' (he)
he (Gennaro) said, climbing out of the Jeep. They hurried forward to the second Land Cruiser. Their f lashlights swung back and forth in the night. As they came closer, Gennaro saw how battered the c ar was. He (Gennaro) was careful to let Muldoon look inside first.
``I wouldn't worry,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``It's very unlike ly we'll find anyone.'' (unknown)
``No?'' (unknown)
``No,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said. He (Muldoon) explained that, during his (Muldoon) years in Africa, he (Muldoon) had visited the scenes of a half- dozen animal attacks on humans in the bush. One leo pard attack: the leopard had torn open a tent in the night and taken a three-year-old child. Then one buffalo attack in Amboseli; two lion attacks; one croc attack in the north, near Meru. I n every case, there was surprisingly little evidence left behind. Inexperienced people imagined horrific proofs of an animal attack-torn limbs left behind in the tent, trails of dripping blood leading away into th e bush, bloodstained clothing not far from the campsite. But the truth was, there was usually noth ing at all, particularly if the victim was small, an infant or a young child. The person just seemed to disappear, as if he (victim) had walked out into the bush and never come back. A predator could kill a c hild just by shaking it, snapping the neck. Usually there wasn't any blood. And most of the time you never found any other rema ins of the victims. Sometimes a button from a shirt, or a sliver of rubber from a shoe. Bu t most of the time, nothing. Predators took children-they preferred children-and they left nothing behind. So Muldoon thought it highly unlikely that they would ever fin d any remains of the children. But as he (Muldoon) looked in now, he (Muldoon) had a surprise.
``I'll b e damned,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said. Muldoon tried to put the scene together. The front windshield of the Land Cruiser was shattered, but there wasn't much glass nearby. He (Muldoon) had noticed shards of glass back on the road. So the windshield must have broken back there, before the tyrannosaur picked the car up and threw it here. But the car had taken a tremendous beating. M uldoon shone his (Muldoon) light inside.
``Empty?'' (Gcnnaro)
Gcnnaro said, tensely.
``Not quite,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. His (Muldoon) flashlight glinted o ff a Crushed radio handset, and on the floor of the car he (Muldoon) saw something else, something curved and black. The front doors were dented and jammed shut, but he (Muldoon) climbed in through the back doo r and crawled over the seat to pick up the black object.
``It's a watch,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said, peering at it in the beam of his (Muldoon) flashlight. A cheap digital watch with a molded black rubber strap. The LCD face was shatter ed, He (Muldoon) thought the boy might have been wearing it, though he (Muldoon) wasn't sure. But it was the k ind of watch a kid would have.
``What is it, a watch?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``Yes. And there's a radio, but it's broken.'' (unknown)
``Is that significant?'' (unknown)
``Yes. And there's something else... '' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon s niffed. There was a sour odor inside the car. He (Muldoon) shone the light around until he (Muldoon) saw the vomit dr ipping off the side door panel. He (Muldoon) touched it: still fresh.
``One of the kids may still be alive,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. Gennaro squinted at him (Muldoon).
``What makes you think so?'' (unknown)

``The watch,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)

H e banded the watch to Gennaro, who held it in the glow of the flashlight, and turned it ove r in his (Muldoon) hands.

Gennaro said.

Muldoon said.
``And the band is unin jured.'' (unknown)

'' Anytime before the attack.'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)

``So the kid took his (kid) watch off.'' (unknown)

Muldoon said.
``If you were being attacked by a tyrannosaur, would you stop to take your watch off?'' (unknown)
``Maybe it was torn off.'' (unknown)

Muldoon said.
``The kid took it off himself. He (kid) looked at his (kid) watch, saw it was broken, and took it off. He (kid) had t he (kid) time to do that.'' (unknown)
``When?'' (unknown)
``It could only have been after the attack,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``The kid must have been in this car, after the attack. And the radio was broken, so he (kid) l eft it behind, too. He (kid)'s a bright kid, and he (kid) knew they weren't useful.'' (unknown)
``If he (kid)'s so bright,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said,
``where'd he (kid) go? Because I'd stay right here and wait to be picked up.'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
``Yes,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
