``That's when it happens,'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)
Malcolm said. Ellie said,
``You don't think much of Arnold, do you ?'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
``He (Arnold)'s all right. He (Arnold)'s an engineer. Wu's the same. T hey're both technicians. They don't have intelligence. They have what I call `thintelligence .' They see the immediate situation. They think narrowly and they call it `being focused.' They don 't see the surround. They don't see the consequences. That's how you get an island like thi s. From thintelligent thinking. Because you cannot make an animal and not expect it to act aliv e. To be unpredictable. To escape. But they don't see that.'' (unknown)
``Don't you think it's just human nature?'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Ellie sai d.
``God, no,'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Malcolm said. ``That's like saying scramb led eggs and bacon for breakfast is human nature. It's nothing of the sort. It's uniquely Wes tern training, and much of the rest of the world is

nauseated by the thought of it.'' He (Malcolm) winced in pain. ``The morphine's making me philosophical.'' ``You want some water?'' ``No. I'll tell you the problem with engineers and s cientists. Scientists have an elaborate line of bullshit about how they are seeking to know the tru th about nature. Which is true, but that's not what drives them. Nobody is driven by abstractions like `seeking truth.' ``Scientists are actually preoccupied with accomplis hment. So they are focused on whether they can do something. They never stop to ask if th ey should do something. They conveniently define such considerations as pointless. If they do n't do it, someone else will. Discovery, they believe, is inevitable. So they just try to do it f irst. That's the game in science. Even pure scienti fic discovery is an aggressive, penetrative act. It tak es big equipment, and it literally changes the world afterward. Particle accelerators sear the lan d, and leave radioactive byproducts. Astronauts leave trash on the moon. There is always some proof that scientists were there, making their discoveries. Discovery is always a rape of the natu ral world. Always. ``The scientists want it that way. They have to stic k their instruments in. They have to leave their mark. They can't just watch. They can't just appreciate. They can't just fit into the natural order. They have to make something unnatural happen . That is the scientist's job, and now we have whole societies that try to be scientific.'' He (Malcolm) sighed, and sank back. Ellie said, ``Don't you think you're overstating-'' ``What does one of your excavations look like a year later?'' ``Pretty had,'' she (Ellie) admitted. ``You don't replant, you don't restore the land afte r you dig?'' ``No.'' ``Why not?'' She (Ellie) shrugged. ``There's no money, I guess...

``There's only enough money to dig, but not to repai r?'' (I)

``Just the badlands,'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)

``Just trash. Just byproducts. Just side effects ... I'm trying to tell you that scientist s want it this way. They want byproducts and trash and scars and side effects. It's a way of reassurin g themselves. It's built into the fabric of science , and it's increasingly a disaster.'' (unknown)
``Then what's the answer?'' (unknown)

(Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)

Twenty hours a week. Thirty thousand years ago.'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)

she (Ellie) said. He (Malcolm) sighed, and closed his (Malcolm) eyes.

In the dark tunnel of the jungle river, Grant went hand over hand, holding branches, moving the raft cautiously forward. He (Grant) still heard the sounds. And finally he (Grant) saw the dinosaurs.
``Aren't those the ones that are poison?'' (unknown)
``Yes,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said.
``Dilophosaurus.'' (unknown)
Standing on the riverbank were two dilophosaurs. Th e ten-foot-tall bodies were spotted yellow and black. Underneath, the bellies were bright gree n, like lizards. Twin red curving crests ran along the top of the head from the eyes to the nose , making a V shape above the head. The bird- like quality was reinforced by the way they moved, bending to drink from the river, then rising to snarl and hoot. Lex whispered,
``Should we get out and walk?'' (Lex)
Grant shook his (Grant) head no. The dilophosaurs were smal ler than the tyrannosaur, small enough to slip through the dense foliage at the banks of t he (Grant) river. And they seemed quick, as they snarled and hooted at each other.
``But we can't get past them in the boat,'' (Lex)
Lex said.
``They're poison.'' (unknown)

Grant said.
``Somehow.'' (unknown)
The dilophosaurs continued to drink and hoot. They seemed to be interacting with each other in a strangely ritualistic, repetitive way. The ani mal on the left would bend to drink, opening its mouth to bare long rows of sharp teeth, and then it would hoot. The animal on the right would boot in reply and bend to drink, in a mirror image of the first animal's movements. Then the sequence would be repeated, exactly the same way. Grant noticed that the animal on the right was smal ler, with smaller spots on its back, and its crest was a duller red-
``I'll be damned,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
he (Grant) said.

``Oh, great '' (Lex)

Tyrannosaur The Jeep bounced along in the glaring sun. Muldoon was driving, with Gennaro at his (Muldoon) side. T hey came to a rise, and Muldoon stopped the car.
``Christ, it's hot,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said, wiping his (Muldoon) forehead wi th the back of his (Muldoon) arm. He (Muldoon) drank from the bottle of

whiskey between his (Muldoon) knees, then offered it to Genna ro. Gennaro shook his (Gennaro) head. He (Gennaro) stared at the landscape shimmering in the morning heat. Gennaro said.

There must be a closed-circuit camera in the trees somewhere behind.
``You want to help,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said,
``you can break ou t those canisters by your feet.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Gennaro bent over and opened a stainless-steel Hall iburton case. It was padded inside with foam. Four cylinders, each the size of a quart milk bottle, were nestled in the foam. They were all labeled MORO-709. He (Muldoon) took one out.
``You snap off the tip and screw on a needle,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Muldo on explained. Gennaro found a plastic package of large needles, e ach the diameter of his (Gennaro) fingertip. He (Gennaro) screwed one onto the canister. The opposite end of the canister had a circular lead weight.
``That's the plunger. Compresses on impact.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon sat forward with the air rifle across his (Muldoon) knees. It was made of heavy gray tubular metal and looked to Gennaro like a bazooka or a rocket launcher.
``What's MORO-709?'' (unknown)
``Standard animal trank,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said,
``Zoos around the world use it. We'll try a thousand cc's to start.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon cracked open the chamber, which was large enough to insert his (Muldoon) fist. He (Muldoon) slipped the canister into the chamber and closed it .
``That should do it,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``Standard elepha nt gets about two hundred cc's, but they're only two or three tons each. Tyrannosaurus rex is e ight tons, and a lot meaner. That matters to the dose.'' (unknown)
``Why?'' (unknown)
``Animal dose is partly body weight and partly tempe rament. You shoot the same dose of 709 into an elephant, a hippo, and a rhino-you'll immob ilize the elephant, so it just stands there like a statue. You'll slow down the hippo, so it gets kind of sleepy but it keeps moving. And the rhino will just get fighting mad. But, on the other hand, you chase a rhino for more than five minutes in a car and he (it)'ll drop dead from adrenaline shock. Stra nge combination of tough and delicate.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon drove slowly toward the river, moving close r to the tyrannosaur.
``But those are all mammals. We know a lot about handling mammals, beca use zoos are built around the big mammalian attractions-lions, tigers, bears, elephan ts. We know a lot less about reptiles. And nobody knows anything about dinosaurs. The dinosaur s are new animals.'' (unknown)
``You consider them reptiles?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``No,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said, shifting gears.
``Dinosaurs don' t fit existing categories.'' (He)
He (Muldoon) swerved to avoid a rock.
``Actually, what we find is, the dinos aurs were as variable as mammals are today. Some dinos are tame and cute, and some are mean and nasty. Some of them see well, and some of them don't. Some of them are stupid, and so me of them are very, very intelligent.'' (unknown)
``Like the raptors?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said. Muldoon nodded.
``Raptors are smart, Very smart. Bel ieve me, all the problems we have so far,'' (he)
he (Muldoon) said,

``You done this very often before?'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon belched.
``Never. I'll try to get him (we) just b ehind the auditory meatus. We'll see how it goes from there.'' (He)
He (Muldoon) walked ten yards behind the Je ep and crouched down in the grass on one knee. He (Muldoon) steadied the big gun against his (Muldoon) shoulder, and flipped up the thick telescopic sight. Muldoon aimed at the tyrannosaur, which still ignor ed them. There was a burst of pale gas, and Gennaro saw a wh ite streak shoot forward in the air toward the tyrannosaur. But nothing seemed to happen. Then the tyrannosaur turned slowly, curiously, to p eer at them. It moved its head from side to side, as if looking at them with alternate eyes. Muldoon had taken down the launcher, and was loadin g the second canister.
``You hit him (we)?'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said. Muldoon shook his (Muldoon) head.

Gennaro said.
``A battery,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said.
``It's about as big as yo ur finger. Gray markings.'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro bent over to look in the steel case. He (Muldoon) fel t the vibration of the Jeep, heard the motor ticking over. He (Muldoon) didn't see a battery. The tyrannos aur roared. To Gennaro it was a terrifying sound, rumbling from the great chest cavity of the animal, bellowing out over the landscape. He (Gennaro) sat up sharply and reached for the steering wheel, put his (Gennaro) hand on the gearshift. On the radio, he (Gennaro) heard a voice say,
``Muldoon. This is Arnold. Get ou t of there. Over.'' (he)
``I know what I'm doing,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said. The

tyrannosaur charged. Muldoon stood his (Muldoon) ground. Despite the creature raci ng toward him (Muldoon), he (Muldoon) slowly and methodically raised his (Muldoon) launcher, aimed, and fired. Once again, Gennaro saw the puff of smoke, and the white streak of the canister going toward the animal. Nothing happened. The tyrannosaur continued to char ge. Now Muldoon was on his (Muldoon) feet and running, shouting,

``Go! Go!'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Gennaro put the Jeep in gear and Muldoon threw himself onto the side door as the Jeep lurched forward. The tyrannosaur was closing rapidly, and Muldoon swung the door open an d climbed inside.
``Go, damn it! Go!'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro floored it. The Jeep bounced precariously, the front end nosing so high they saw only sky through the windshield, then slamming down agai n toward the ground and racing forward again. Gennaro headed for a stand of trees to the l eft until, in the rearview mirror, he (Gennaro) saw the tyrannosaur give a final roar and turn away. Gennaro slowed the car.
``Jesus.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon was shaking his (Muldoon) head.
``I could have sworn I hit him (Jesus) the second time.'' (unknown)

Gennaro said.

The Jeep headed north, toward the hotel. Muldoon pi cked up the radio.

``Yes,'' (Arnold/Mr. Arnold)
Arnold said.
``We're heading back to base.'' (unknown)
The river was now very narrow, and flowing swiftly. The raft was going faster all the time. It was starting to feel like an amusement park ride.
``Whee!'' (Lex)
Lex yelled, holding on to the gunwale.
``Fas ter, faster!'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant squinted, looking forward. The river was stil l narrow and dark, but farther ahead he (Grant) could see the trees ended, and there was bright sunlight beyond, and a distant roaring sound. The river seemed to end abruptly in a peculiar flat line... . The raft was going still faster, rushing forward. G rant grabbed for his (Grant) paddles.
``What is it?'' (unknown)
``It's a waterfall,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. The raft swept out of the overhanging darkness into brilliant morning sunlight, and raced forward on the swift current toward the lip of the waterfall. The roar was loud in their ears. Grant paddled as strongly as he (Grant) could, but he (Grant) only succee ded in spinning the boat in circles. It continued inexorably toward the lip. Lex leaned toward him (Lex).
``I can't swim!'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant saw th at she (Lex) did not have her (Lex) life vest clasped, but there was nothing he (Grant) could do about it; with fr ightening speed, they came to the edge, and the roar of the waterfall seemed to fill the world. Grant jammed his (Grant) oar deep into the water, it catch and hold, right at the lip; the rubber raft s huddered in the current, but they did not go over. Grant strained against the oar and, looking over th e edge, saw the sheer drop of fifty feet down to the surging pool below. And standing in the surging pool, waiting for them, was the tyrannosaur. Lex was screaming in panic, and then the boat spun, and the rear end dropped away, spilling them out into air and roaring water, and they fell sickeningly. Grant flailed his (Grant) arms in the air, and

the world went suddenly silent and slow. It seemed to him (Grant) he (Grant) fell for long minutes; he (Grant) had t ime to observe Lex, clutching her (Grant) orange jacket, falling alongside him (Lex); he (Lex) had time to observe Tim, looking down at the bottom; he (Lex) had time to observe the frozen white sheet of the waterfall; he (Lex) had time to observe the bubbling pool beneath him (Lex) as he (Lex) fell slowly, silently toward it. Then, with a stinging slap, Grant plunged into cold water, surrounded by white boiling bubbles. He (Grant) tumbled and spun and glimpsed the leg of the tyr annosaur as he (Grant) was swirled past it, swept down through the pool and out into the stream beyon d. Grant swam for the shore, clutched warm rocks, slipped off, caught a branch, and finally pu lled himself out of the main current. Gasping, he (Grant) dragged himself on his (Grant) belly onto the rocks, and lo oked at the river just in time to see the brown rubber raft tumble past him (Grant). Then he (Grant) saw Tim, battl ing the current, and he (Grant) reached out and pulled him (Grant), coughing and shivering, onto the shore beside him (Grant). Grant turned back to the waterfall, and saw the tyr annosaur plunge its head straight down into the water of the pool at his (Grant) feet. The great head s hook, splashing water to either side. It had something between its teeth. And then the tyrannosaur lifted its head back up. D angling from the jaws was Lex's orange life vest. A moment later, Lex bobbed to the surface beside th e dinosaur's long tail. She (Grant) lay face down in the water, her (Grant) little body swept downstream by the current. Grant plunged into the water after her (Grant), was again immersed in the churning torrent. A momen t later, he (Grant) pulled her (Grant) up onto the rocks, a heavy, lifeless weight. Her (Grant) face was gray. Water po ured from her (Grant) mouth. Grant bent over her (Grant) to give her (Grant) mouth-to-mouth but she (Grant) coughed. Then she (Grant) vomited yellow- green liquid and coughed again. Her (Grant) eyelids flutter ed.

``Hi,'' (she)
she (Grant) said. She (Grant) smiled weakly.
``We did it.'' (Tim)
Tim started to cry. She (Grant) coughed again.
``Will you st op it? What're you crying for?'' (unknown)
``Because.'' (unknown)
``We were worried about you,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. Small flec ks of white were drifting down the river. The tyrannosaur was tearing up the life vest. Still turned away from them, facing the waterfall. But at any minute the animal might turn and see them. . . . Come on, kids,'' he (Grant) said. ``Where are we going?'' Lex said, coughing. ``Come on.
'' He (Lex) was looking for a hiding place. Downs tream he (Lex) saw only an open grassy plain, affording no protection. Upstream was the dinosaur. Then Grant saw a dirt path by the river. It seemed to lead up toward the waterfall. And in the dirt he (Grant) saw the clear imprint of a man's shoe. Leading up the path. The tyrannosaur finally turned around, growling and looking out toward the grassy plain. It seemed to have figured out that they had gotten awa y. It was looking for them downstream. Grant and the k ids ducked among the big ferns that lined the riverbanks. Cautiously, he (Grant) led them upstream. '' (unknown)
Where are we going?'' Lex said. ``We're going back.'' ``I know.'' They were closer to the waterfall now, the roar muc h louder. The rocks became slippery, the path muddy. There was a constant hanging mist. It w as like moving through a cloud. The path seemed to lead right into the rushing water, but as they came closer, they saw that it actually went behind the waterfall. The tyrannosaur was still looking downstream, its b ack turned to them. They hurried along the path to the waterfall, and had almost moved behind the sheet of falling water when Grant saw the tyrannosaur turn. Then they were completely behind the waterfall, and Grant was unable to see out through the silver sheet. Grant looked around in surprise. There was a little recess here, hardly larger than a closet, and filled with machinery: humming pumps and big filter s and pipes. Everything was wet, and cold. ``Did he (We) see us?'' Lex said. She (its) had to shout over th e noise of the falling water. ``Where are we? What is this place? Did he (We) see us?'' ``Just a minute,'' Grant said. He (Grant) was looking at the equipment. This was clearly park machinery. And there must be electricity to run it, so perhaps there was also a telephone for communication. He (Grant) poked among the filters and pipes. ``What are you doing?'' Lex shouted. ``Looking for a telephone.'' It was now nearly 10:00 a.m.. They had just a little more than an hour to contact the ship before it reached the main land. In the back of the recess he (Lex) found a metal door mar ked MAINT 04, but it was firmly locked. Next to it was a slot for a security card. Alongsid e the door he (Lex) saw a row of metal boxes. He (Lex) opened the boxes one after another, but they contai ned only switches and timers. No telephone. And nothing to open the door. He (Lex) almost missed the box to the left of the door. O n opening it, he (Lex) found a nine-button keypad, covered with spots of green mold. But it looked as if it was a way to open the door, and he (Lex) had the feeling that on the other side of that door was a phone. Scratched in the metal of the box was the number 1023. He (Lex) punched it in. With a hiss, the door came open. Gaping darkness be yond, concrete steps leading downward. On the back wall he (Lex) saw stenciled MAINT VEHICLE 04/ 22 CHARGER and an arrow pointing down the stairs. Could it really mean there was a c ar? ``Come on, kids.'' ``Forget it,'' Lex said.

Lex said.
``There's no lights or anythi ng. I'm not going.'' (unknown)
``Never mind,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. There wasn't time to argu e.
``Stay here, and I'll be right back.'' (unknown)
``Where're you going?'' (Lex)
Lex said, suddenly alarmed. Grant stepped through the door. It gave an electron ic beep, and snapped shut behind him (Grant), on a spring. Grant was plunged into total darkness. After a mome nt of surprise, he (Grant) turned to the door and felt its damp surface. There was no knob, no latch. He (Grant) turned to the walls on either side of the door, feeling for a switch, a control box, anything at all... . There was nothing. He (Grant) was fighting panic when his (Grant) fingers closed over a cold metal cylinder. He (Grant) ran his (Grant) hands over a swelling edge, a flat surface ... a flashl ight! He (Grant) clicked it on, and the beam was surprisingly bright. He (Grant) looked back at the door, bu t saw that it would not open. He (Grant) would have to wait for the kids to unlock it. Meantime ... He (Grant) started for the steps. They were damp and slippe ry with mold, and he (Grant) went down carefully. Partway down the stairs, he (Grant) heard a sniffing and th e sound of claws scratching on concrete. He (Grant) took out his (Grant) dart pistol, and proceeded cautiously.

The steps bent around the corner, and as he (Grant) shone h is light, an odd reflection glinted back, and then, a moment later, he (Grant) saw it: a car! It was an electric car, like a golf cart, and it faced a long tunnel that seemed to stretch away for miles. A bright red light glowed by the steering wheel of the car, so perhaps it was charged. Grant heard the sniffing again, and he (Grant) wheeled and saw a pale shape rise up toward him (Grant), leaping through the air, its laws open, and without thinking Grant fired. The animal landed on him (Grant), knocking him (Grant) down, and he (Grant) rolled away in fright, hi s flashlight swinging wildly. But the animal didn't get up, and he (Grant) felt foolish when he (Grant) saw it. It was a velociraptor, but very young, less than a year old. It was about two feet tall, the size of a medium dog, and it lay on the ground, breathing s hallowly, the dart sticking from beneath its jaw. There was probably too much anesthetic for its body weight, and Grant pulled the dart out quickly. The velociraptor looked at him (Grant) with slight ly glazed eyes. Grant had a clear feeling of intelligence from this creature, a kind of softness which contrasted strangely with the menace he (Grant) had felt from the adul ts in the pen. He (Grant) stroked the head of the velociraptor, hoping to calm it. He (Grant) looked down at the body, which was shivering slightly as the tranquilizer took hold. And then he (Grant) saw it was a ma le. A young juvenile, and a male. There was no question what he (male) was seeing. This velociraptor had been bred in the wild. Excited by this development, he (male) hurried back up the stairs to the door. With his (male) flashlight, he (male) scanned the flat, featureless surface of the door, and the interior walls. As he (male) ran his (male) hands over the door, it slowly dawned on him (male) that he (male) was locke d inside, and unable to open it, unless the kids had the presence of mind to open it for him (male). H e could hear them, faintly, on the other side of the door.

And then, with a roar, the tyrannosaur's head burst through the waterfall toward them. Tim stared in horror as the big mouth gaped wide. L ex shrieked and threw herself on the ground. The head swung back and forth, and pulled o ut again. But Tim could see the shadow of the animal's head on the sheet of falling water. He (Tim) pulled Lex deeper into the recess, just as the j aws burst through again, roaring, the thick tongue flicking in and out rapidly. Water sprayed i n all directions from the head. Then it pulled out again. Lex huddled next to Tim, shivering.
``I hate him (Grant),'' (he)
s he (Lex) said. She (herself) huddled back, but the recess was only a few feet deep, and crammed with machiner y. There wasn't any place for them to hide. But the eyes were still outside the sheet of water. Tim thought: He (Tim) can't see us. He (Tim) knows we're in her (herself) e, but he (Tim) can't see through the water. The tyrannosaur sniffed.
``What is he (Grant) doing?'' (Lex)
Lex said again.
``Sshhbh.'' (unknown)
With a low growl, the jaws slowly opened, and the t ongue snaked out. It was thick and blue- black, with a little forked indentation at the tip. It was four feet long, and easily reached back to the far wall of the recess. The tongue slid with a rasping scrape over the filter cylinders. Tim and Lex pressed back against the pipes. The tongue moved slowly to the left, then to the ri ght, slapping wetly against the machinery. The tip curled around the pipes and valves, sensing them. Tim saw that the tongue had muscular movements, like an elephant's trunk, The tongue dre w back along the right side of the recess. It dragged against Lex's legs.
``Eeww,'' (Lex)
Lex said. The tongue stopped. It curled, then began to rise l ike a snake up the side of her (Lex) body-
``Don't move, '' (Tim)
Tim whispered. ... past her (Lex) face, then up along Tim's shoulder, and finally wrapping around his (Tim) head. Tim squeezed his (Tim) eyes shut as the slimy muscle covered his (Tim) face. It was hot and wet and it stunk like urine. Wrapped around him (Tim), the tongue began to drag him (Tim), v ery slowly, toward the open laws.
``Timmy ...'' (Tim)
Tim couldn't answer; his (Tim) mouth was covered by the f lat black tongue. He (Tim) could see, but he (Tim) couldn't talk. Lex tugged at his (Lex) hand.
``Come on, Timmy!'' (him)
The tongue dragged him (Lex) toward the snorting mouth. H e felt the hot panting breath on his (Lex) legs. Lex was tugging at him (Lex) but she (Tim) was no match for the muscular power that held him (Lex). Tim let go of her (Tim) and pressed the tongue with both hands, trying to shove it over his (Tim) head. He (Tim) couldn't move it. He (Tim) dug his (Tim) heels into the muddy ground but he (Tim) was d ragged forward anyway. Lex had wrapped her (Tim) arms around his (Lex) waist and was p ulling backward, shouting to him (Lex), but he (Lex) was powerless to do anything. He (Lex) was beginning to s ee stars. A kind of peacefulness overcame him (Lex), a sense of peaceful inevitability as he (Lex) was dr agged along. Timmy?'' And then suddenly the tongue relaxed, and uncoiled. Tim felt it slipping off his (Tim) face. His (Tim) body was covered in disgusting white foamy slime, and th e tongue fell limply to the ground. The jaws slapped shut, biting down on the tongue. Dark blood gushed out, mixing with the mud. The nostrils still snorted in ragged breaths. ``What's he (Timmy) doing?'' Lex cried. And then slowly, very slowly, the head began to sli de backward, out of the recess, leaving a long scrape in the mud. And finally it disappeared entirely, and they could see only the silver sheet of falling water. Control ``Okay,'' Arnold said, in the control room. ``The rex is down.'' He (Arnold) pushed back in his (Arnold) chair, and grinned as he (Arnold) lit a final cigarette and crumpled th e pack. That did it: the final step in putting the park back in order. Now all they had to do was go o ut and move it. ``Son of a bitch,'' Muldoon said, looking at the moni tor. ``I got him (Son) after all.'' He (Muldoon) turned to Gennaro. ``It just took him (Son) an hour to feel it.'' Henry Wu frowned at the screen. ``But he (Son) could drown , in that position...'' ``He (Son) won't drown,'' Muldoon said. ``Never seen an anim al that was harder to kill.'' ``I think we have to go out and move him (Son),'' Arnold sa id, ``We will,'' Muldoon said. He (Muldoon) didn't sound enthusiastic. ``That's a valuable animal.'' ``I know it's a valuable animal,'' Muldoon said. Arnold turned to Gennaro. He (Arnold) couldn't resist a mome nt of triumph. ``I'd point out to you,'' he (Arnold) said, ``that the park is now completely back to norm al.. Whatever Malcolm's mathematical model said was going to happen. We are completely under c ontrol again.'' Gennaro pointed to the screen behind Arnold's head and said, ``What's that?'' Arnold turned. It was the system status box, in the upper corner of the screen. Ordinarily it was empty. Arnold was surprised to see that it was now blinking yellow: AUX PWR LOW. For a moment, he (Arnold) didn't understand. Why should auxiliary power be low? They were running on main power, not auxiliary power. He (Arnold) thought perhaps it w as just a routine status check on the auxiliary power, perhaps a check on the fuel tank levels or t he (Arnold) battery charge... ``Henry,'' Arnold said to Wu. ``Look at this.'' Wu said, ``Why are you running on auxiliary power?'' ``I'm not,'' Arnold said. ``It looks like you are.'' ``I can't be.'' ``Print the system status log,'' Wu said. The log was a record of the system over the last few hours. Arnold pressed a button, and they heard the hum of a printer in the corner. Wu walked over to it. Arnold stared at the screen. The box now turned fro m flashing yellow to red, and the message now read: AUX PWR FAIL, Numbers began to count back ward from twenty. ``What the hell is going on?'' Arnold said. Cautiously, Tim moved a few yards out along the mud dy path, into the sunshine. He (Arnold) peered around the waterfall, and saw the tyrannosaur lying on its side, floating in the pool of water below. ``I hope he (Henry)'s dead,'' Lex said. Tim could see he (Tim) wasn't: the dinosaur's chest was s till moving, and one forearm twitched in spasms. But something was wrong with him (Tim). Then Tim saw the white canister sticking in the back of the head, by the indentation of the ear. ``He (Henry)'s been shot with a dart,'' Tim said. ``Good,'' Lex said. ``He (Henry) practically ate us.'' Tim watched the labored breathing. He (Tim) felt unexpect edly distressed to see the huge animal humbled like this. He (Tim) didn't want it to die. ``It's not his (Henry) fault,'' he (Tim) said. ``Oh sure,'' Lex said. ``He (Henry) practically ate us and it' s not his (Henry) fault.''
``He (Henry)'s a carnivore. He (Henry) was just doing what he (Henry) does.'' (unknown)

``You wouldn't say that,'' (Lex)
Lex said, ``if you were in his (Henry) stomach right now. Then the sound of the waterfall changed. From a dea fening roar, it became softer, quieter. The thundering sheet of water thinned, became a trickle ... And stopped. ``Timmy. The waterfall stopped,'' Lex said. It was now just dripping like a tap that wasn't com pletely turned off. The pool at the base of the waterfall was still. They stood near the top, in th e cave-like indentation filled with machinery, looking down. ``Waterfalls aren't supposed to stop,'' Lex said. Tim shook his (Tim) head. ``It must be the power... . So mebody turned off the power.'' Behind them, all the pumps and filters were shutting down one af ter another, the lights blinking off, and the machinery becoming quiet. And then there was the thunk of a solenoid releasin g, and the door marked MAINT 04 swung slowly open. Grant stepped out, blinking in the light, and said, ``Good work, kids. You got the door open.'' ``We didn't do anything,'' Lex said. ``The

power went out,'' Tim said. ``Never mind that,'' Grant said. ``Come and see what I 've found.'' Arnold stared in shock. Muldoon opened the blinds and let light in, and Wu brought over the pr intout. ``Look at this,'' Wu said. Apparently, main power had no t been on since shutdown. When he (Arnold) powered back up, only the auxiliary power came on. Arnold was thinking that was strange, when he (Arnold) suddenly realized that that was normal. That was what was supposed to happen. It made perfect sense: the auxiliary generator fired up fir st, and it was used to turn on the main generator, because it took a heavy charge to start the main po wer generator. That was the way the system was designed. But Arnold had never before had occasion to turn th e main power off. And when the lights and screens came back on in the control room, it never occurred to him (Arnold) that main power hadn't also been restored. But it hadn't, and all during the time since then, while they were looking for the rex, and doing one thing and another, the park had been running on auxilary power. And that wasn't a good idea. In fact, the implications were just beginning to hit him (Arnold)- ``What does this line mean?'' Muldoon said, pointing to the list. 05:14:57 Warning: Fence Status -LSB-NB-RSB- Operative - Aux Power -LSB--AV09-RSB- ``It means a system status warning was sent to the m onitors in the control room,'' Arnold said. ``Concerning the fences.'' ``Did you see that warning?'' Arnold shook his (Arnold) head, ``No. I must have been talkin g to you in the field. Anyway, no, I didn't see it.'' ``What does it mean, `Warning: Fence Status'?'' ``Well, I didn't know it at the time, but we were ru nning on backup power,'' Arnold said. ``And backup doesn't generate enough amperage to power th e electrified fences, so they were automatically kept off.'' ``The thing about these damn dinos,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon said,
'' is that they have distributed nervous systems. They don't die fast, even with a direct hi t to the brain. And they're built solidly; thick ri bs make a shot to the heart dicey, and they're difficu lt to cripple in the legs or hindquarters. Slow bleeders, slow to die.'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)

The raptors were snarling at Arnold when the animal on the left simply exploded, the upper part of the torso flying into the air, blood spattering like a burst tomato on the walls of the building. Muldoon said. Arnold ran for the door of the maintenance shed. Th e velociraptors turned, and started toward Muldoon and Gennaro. They fanned out as they came c loser. In the distance, somewhere near the lodge, he (Gennaro) heard screams. Gennaro said,

M uldoon said. Henry Wu heard the explosions and looked toward the door of the control room. He (Gennaro) circled around the consoles, then paused. He (Gennaro) wanted to go o ut, but he (Gennaro) knew he (Gennaro) should stay in the room. If Arnold was able to get the power back on-if only for a minute-then Wu could restart the main generator. He (Wu) had to stay in the room. He (Wu) heard someone screaming. It sounded like Muldoon . Muldoon felt a wrenching pain in his (Muldoon) ankle, tumbled down an embankment, and hit the ground running. Looking back, he (Muldoon) saw Gennaro running in th e other direction, into the forest. The raptors were ignoring Gennaro but pursuing Muldoon. They we re now less than twenty yards away. Muldoon screamed at the top of his (Muldoon) lungs as he (Muldoon) ran, wondering vaguely where the hell he (Muldoon) could go. Because he (Muldoon) knew he (Muldoon) had perhaps ten seconds befo re they got him (Muldoon). Ten seconds. Maybe

less. Ellie had to help Malcolm turn over as Harding jabb ed the needle and injected morphine. Malcolm sighed and collapsed back. It seemed be was growing weaker by the minute. ``What is he (God) talking about?'' (Hammond/Hammond Foundation/Foundation)
Harding made a sign, indicating delirium. Malcolm c ocked his (Malcolm) eye.
``I will tell you what I am talking about,'' (he)
he (Malcolm) said. ``Most kinds of power require a substantial sacrifice by whoever wants the power. There is an a pprenticeship, a discipline lasting many years. Whatever kind of power you want. President o f the company. Black belt in karate. Spiritual guru. Whatever it is you seek, you have to put in t he (guru) time, the practice, the effort. You must give up a lot to get it. It has to be very important to you. And once you have attained it, it is your power. It can't be given away: it resides in you. I t is literally the result of your discipline. ``Now, what is interesting about this process is tha t, by the time someone has acquired the ability to kill with his (guru) bare hands, he (guru) has also ma tured to the point where he (guru) won't use it unwisely. So that kind of power has a built-in control. The d iscipline of getting the power changes you so that you won't abuse it. ``But scientific power is like inherited wealth: att ained without discipline. You read what others have done, and you take the next step. You can do i t very young. You can make progress very fast. There is no discipline lasting many decades. There is no mastery: old scientists are ignored. There is no humility before nature. There is only a get-rich-quick, make-a-name-for-yourself-fast philosophy. Cheat, lie, falsify-it doesn't matter. Not to you, or to your colleagues. No one will criticize you. No one has any standards. They are a ll trying to do the same thing: to do something big, and do it fast. ``And because you can stand on the shoulders of gian ts, you can accomplish something quickly. You don't even know exactly what you have done, but already you have reported it, patented it, and sold it. And the buyer will have e ven less discipline than you. The buyer simply purchases the power, like any commodity. The buyer doesn't even conceive that any discipline might be necessary.'' Hammond said, ``Do you know what he (buyer) is talking about ?'' Ellie nodded. ``I haven't a clue,'' Hammond said. ``I'll make it simple,'' Malcolm said. ``A karate mast er does not kill people with his (buyer) bare hands. He (buyer) does not lose his (buyer) temper and kill his (buyer) wife. The person who kills is the person who has no discipline, no restraint, and who has purchased his (buyer) power in the form of a Saturday night special. And that is the kind of power that science fosters, and permits. And that is why you think that to build a place like this is simple.'' ``It was simple,'' Hammond insisted. ``Then why did it go wrong?'' Dizzy with tension, John Arnold threw open the door to the maintenance shed and stepped into the darkness inside. Jesus, it was black. He (Jesus) should have realized the lights would be out. He (Jesus) felt the cool air, the cavernous dimensions of the space , extending two floors below him (Jesus). He (Jesus) had to find the catwalk. He (Jesus) had to be careful, or he (Jesus)'d bre ak his (Jesus) neck. The catwalk. He (Jesus) groped like a blind man until he (Jesus) realized it was futile. Somehow he (Jesus) had to get light into the shed, He (Jesus) went back to the door and cracked it open four inches. That gave enough light. But there was no way to keep the door open. Quickly he (Jesus) kicked off his (Jesus) shoe and stuck it in the door. He (Jesus) went toward the catwalk, seeing it easily. He (Jesus) wa lked along the corrugated metal, hearing the difference in his (Jesus) feet, one loud, one soft. But at least he (Jesus) could see. Up ahead was the stairway leading down to the generators. Another te n yards. Darkness. The light was gone. Arnold looked back to the door, and saw the light w as blocked by the body of a velociraptor. The animal bent over, and carefully sniffed the sho e. Henry Wu paced. He (Wu) ran his (Wu) hands over the computer consoles. He (Wu) touched the screens. He (Wu) was in constant movement. He (Wu) was almost frantic wit b tension. He (Wu) reviewed the steps he (Wu) would take. He (Wu) must be qui ck. The first screen would come up, and he (Wu) would press- ``Wu!'' The radio hissed. He (Wu) grabbed for it. ``Yes. I'm here.'' ``Got any bloody power yet?'' It was Muldoon. There w as something odd about his (Muldoon) voice, something hollow. ``No,'' Wu said. He (Wu) smiled, glad to know Muldoon was alive. ``I think Arnold made it to the shed,'' Muldoon said- ``After that, I don't know.'' ``Where are you?'' Wu said. ``I'm stuffed.'' ``What?'' ``Stuffed in a bloody pipe,'' Muldoon said. ``And I'm very popular at the moment.'' Wedged in a pipe was more like it, Muldoon thought. There had been a stack of drainage pipes piled behind the visitor center, and he (Muldoon)'d backed hi mself into the nearest one, scrambling like a poor bastard. Meter pipes, very tight fit for him (bastard), but they couldn't come in after him (bastard). At least, not after he (bastard)'d shot the leg off one, when the nosy bastard came too close to the pipe. The raptor had gone howling off, and the others wer e now respectful. His (bastard) only regret was that he (bastard) hadn't waited to see the snout at the end of the tu be before he (bastard)'d squeezed the trigger. But he (bastard) might still have his (bastard) chance, because there w ere three or four outside, snarling and growling around him (bastard). ``Yes, very popular,'' he (bastard) said into the radio. Wu said, ``Does Arnold have a radio?'' ``Don't think so,'' Muldoon said. ``Just sit tight. Wa it it out.'' He (Muldoon) hadn't seen what the other end of the pipe was l ike-he'd backed in too quickly-and he (Muldoon) couldn't see now. He (Muldoon) was wedged tight. He (Muldoon) could onl y hope that the far end wasn't open. Christ, he (Christ) didn't like the thought of one of those bastards taking a bite of his (Christ) hindquarters. Arnold backed away down the catwalk. The velocirapt or was barely ten feet away, stalking him (Arnold), coming forward into the gloom. Arnold could hear th e click of its deadly claws on the metal. But he (Arnold) was going slowly. He (Arnold) knew the animal could s ee well, but the grille of the catwalk, the unfamiliar mechanical odors had made it cautious. T hat caution was his (Arnold) only chance, Arnold thought. If he (Arnold) could get to the stairs, and then mo ve down to the floor below ... Because he (Arnold) was pretty sure velociraptors couldn't c limb stairs. Certainly not narrow, steep stairs. Arnold glanced over his (Arnold) shoulder. The stairs were j ust a few feet away. Another few steps ... He (Arnold) was there! Reaching back, he (Arnold) felt the railing, s tarted scrambling down the almost vertical steps. His (Arnold) feet touched flat concrete. The raptor s narled in frustration, twenty feet above him (Arnold) on the catwalk.

Arnold said. He (Arnold) turned away. He (Arnold) w as now very close to the auxiliary generator. Just a few more steps and he (Arnold) would see i t, even in this dim light... . There was a dull thump behind him (Arnold). Arnold

turned. The raptor was standing there on the concrete floor , snarling. It had jumped down. He (Arnold) looked quickly for a weapon, but suddenly he (Arnold) fou nd he (Arnold) was slammed onto his (Arnold) back on the concrete. Something heavy was pressing on his (Arnold) chest , it was impossible to breathe, and he (Arnold) realized the animal was standing on top of him (Arnold), and he (Arnold) felt the big claws digging into the flesh of his (Arnold) chest, and smelled the foul breath from the hea d moving above him (Arnold), and he (Arnold) opened his (Arnold) mouth to scream. Gennaro crouched in the foliage, listening. Directly ahead he (Gennaro) saw the planted pathway, leading toward the visitor center. Gennaro knew the maintenance shed was somewhere to the east. He (Gennaro) heard the chirping of birds in the trees. A soft mist was blowing. One of the raptors roared, b ut it was some distance away. It sounded off to his (Gennaro) right. Gennaro set out, leaving the path, plung ing into the foliage. Like to live dangerously? Not

really. It was true, he (Gennaro) didn't. But Gennaro thought he (Gennaro) had a plan, or at least a possibility that might work. If he (Gennaro) stayed north of the main complex of bui ldings, he (Gennaro) could approach the maintenance shed from the rear. All the raptors were probably a round the other buildings, to the south. There was no reason for them to be in the jungle. At least, he (Gennaro) hoped not. He (Gennaro) moved as quietly as he (Gennaro) could, unhappily aware he (Gennaro) was making a lot of noise. He (Gennaro) forced himself to slow his (Gennaro) pace, feeling his (Gennaro) heart pound. The foliage here was very dense; he (Gennaro) couldn't see more than six or seven feet ahead of him (Gennaro). He (Gennaro) be gan to worry that he (Gennaro)'d miss the maintenance shed entirely. But then he (Gennaro) saw the roof to his (Gennaro) righ t, above the palms. He (Gennaro) moved toward it, went around the side. He (Gennaro) found the door, opened it, and slipped inside. It was very dark. He (Gennaro) stumbled over something. A man's shoe. Gennaro frowned. He (Gennaro) propped the door wide open and continued deeper into the building. He (Gennaro) saw a catwalk directly ahead of him (Gennaro). Suddenly he (Gennaro) re alized he (Gennaro) didn't know where to go. And he (Gennaro) had left his (Gennaro) radio behind. Damn! There might be a radio somewhere in the maintenance building. Or else he (Gennaro)'d just look for the generator. He (Gennaro) knew what a generator looked like. Pr obably it was somewhere down on the lower floor. He (Gennaro) found a staircase leading down. It was darker below, and it was difficult to see an ything. He (Gennaro) felt his (Gennaro) way along among the pipes, holding his (Gennaro) bands out to keep from banging his (Gennaro) head . He (Gennaro) heard an animal snarl, and froze. He (Gennaro) listened, b ut the sound did not come again. He (Gennaro) moved forward cautiously. Something dripped on his (Gennaro) should er, and his (Gennaro) bare arm. It was warm, like water. He (Gennaro) touched it in the darkness. Sticky. He (Gennaro) smelled it. Blood. He (Gennaro) looked up. The raptor was perched on pipes, just a few feet above his (Gennaro) head. Blood was trickling from its claws. With an odd sense of deta chment, he (Gennaro) wondered if it was injured. And then he (Gennaro) began to run, but the raptor jumped onto his (Gennaro) bac k, pushing him (Gennaro) to the ground. Gennaro was strong; he (Gennaro) heaved up, knocking the rapt or away, and rolled off across the concrete. When he (Gennaro) turned back, he (Gennaro) saw that the rapt or had fallen on its side, where it lay panting. Yes, it was injured. Its leg was hurt, for some rea son. Kill it Gennaro scrambled to his (Gennaro) feet, looking for a weapon . The raptor was still panting on the concrete. He (Gennaro) looked frantically for sometbing-anyth ing-to use as a weapon. When he (Gennaro) turned back, the raptor was gone. It snarled, the sound echoing in the darkness. Gennaro turned in a full circle, feeling with his (Gennaro) o utstretched hands. And then he (Gennaro) felt a sharp pain in his (Gennaro) right hand. Teeth. It was biting him (Gennaro). The raptor jerked his (Gennaro) head, and Donald Gennaro was yanked off his (Gennaro) feet, and he (Gennaro) fell. Lying in bed, soaked in sweat, Malcolm listened as the radio crackled.

``Just relax,'' (Ellie/Ellie Sattler/Sattler)
Ellie said.
``Just take it easy.'' (unknown)
``You know what we are really talking about here,'' (unknown)
M alcolm said. ``All this attempt to control ... We are talking about Western attitudes that are fiv e hundred years old. They began at the time when Florence, Italy, was the most important city i n the world. The basic idea of science-that there was a new way to look at reality, that it was objective, that it did not depend on your beliefs or your nationality, that it was rational-that idea was fresh and exciting back then. It offered promise and hope for the future, and it swept away the old medieval system, which was hundreds of years old. The medieval world of feudal politics and religious dogma and hateful superstitions fell before science. But, in truth, this was becaus e the medieval world didn't really work any more. It didn't work economically, it didn't work intelle ctually, and it didn't fit the new world that was emerging. Malcolm coughed. ``But now,'' he (Malcolm) continued, ``science is the belief sys tem that is hundreds of years old. And, like the medieval system before it, science is starting not to fit the world any more. Science has attained so much power that its practical limits be gin to be apparent. Largely through science, billions of us live in one small world, densely pac ked and intercommunicating. But science cannot help us decide what to do with that world, or how t o live. Science can make a nuclear reactor, but it cannot tell us not to build it. Science can make pesticide, but cannot tell us not to use it. And our world starts to seem polluted in fundamental wa ys-air, and water, and land-because of ungovernable science.'' He (Malcolm) sighed. ``This much is obv ious to everyone.'' There was a silence. Malcolm lay with his (Malcolm) eyes clos ed, his (Malcolm) breathing labored. No one spoke, and it seemed to Ellie that Malcolm had finally fal len asleep. Then he (Malcolm) sat up again, abruptly. ``At the same time, the great intellectual justifica tion of science has vanished. Ever since Newton and Descartes, science has explicitly offere d us the vision of total control. Science has claimed the power to eventually control everything, through its understanding of natural laws. But in the twentieth century, that claim has been shatt ered beyond repair. First, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle set limits on what we could k now about the subatomic world. Oh well, we say. None of us lives in a subatomic world. It does n't make any practical difference as we go through our lives. Then G``del's theorem set similar limits to mathematics, the formal language of science. Mathematicians used to think that their la nguage had some special inherent trueness that derived from the laws of logic. Now we know th at what we call `reason' is just an arbitrary game. It's not special, in the way we thought it wa s. ``And now chaos theory proves that unpredictability is built into our daily lives. It is as mundane as the rainstorm we cannot predict. And so the gran d vision of science, hundreds of years old-the dream of total control-has died, in our century. An d with it much of the justification, the rationale for science to do what it does. And for us to liste n to it. Science has always said that it may not know everything now but it will know, eventually. B ut now we see that isn't true. It is an idle boast.

As foolish, and as misguided, as the child who jump s off a building because he (it) believes he (it) can fly.'' ``This is very extreme,'' Hammond said, shaking his (Hammond) h ead. ``We are witnessing the end of the scientific era. S cience, like other outmoded systems, is destroying itself. As it gains in power, it proves itself incapable of handling the power. Because things are going very fast now. Fifty years ago, ev eryone was gaga over the atomic bomb. That was power. No one could imagine anything more. Yet, a bare decade after the bomb, we began to have genetic power. And genetic power is far mor e potent than atomic power. And it will be in everyone's hands. It will be in kits for backyard g ardeners. Experiments for schoolchildren. Cheap labs for terrorists and dictators, And that will fo rce everyone to ask the same question-What should I do with my power?-which is the very questi on science says it cannot answer.'' ``So what will happen?'' Ellie said. Malcolm shrugged. ``A change.'' ``What kind of change?'' ``All major changes are like death,'' he (Malcolm) said. ``You c an't see to the other side until you are there.'' And he (Malcolm) closed his (Malcolm) eyes. ``The poor man,'' Hammond said, shaking his (Hammond) head. Malcolm sighed. ``Do you have any idea,'' he (Malcolm) said,

``h ow unlikely it is that you, or any of us, will get off this island alive?'' (unknown)
SIXTH ITERATION

``System recovery may prove impossible.'' (unknown)
IAN MALCOLM Return Its electric motor whirring, the cart raced forward down the dark underground tunnel. Grant drove, his (Grant) foot to the floor. The tunnel was featureless e xcept for the occasional air vent above, shaded to protect against rainfall, and thus permitting li ttle light to enter. But he (Grant) noticed that there were

crusty white animal droppings in many places. Obvio usly lots of animals had been in here. Sitting beside him (Grant) in the cart, Lex shone the flash light to the back, where the velociraptor lay.

``they have a bite pressure of fifteen thousand pounds a square inch. They're like hyenas, they can bite through steel an d-'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)

Grant said again. Muldoon said,

The radio clicked off. In the skylight above Malcolm's bed, the raptors ha d chewed through the first of the steel bars. One raptor gripped the end of the bar and tugged, p ulling it back. It put its powerful hind limb on the skylight and the glass shattered, glittering do wn on Malcolm's bed below. Ellie reached over and removed the largest fragments from the sheets.
``God, they're ugly,'' (Malcolm/Ian Malcolm)

The lobby was quiet, chilly fog drifting past them. The radio had been silent for several minutes. Tim said, ``Why aren't they talking to us?'' ``I'm hungry,'' Lex said. ``They're trying to plan,'' Grant said. The radio crackled. ``Grant, are you-nry Wu speaking . Are you there?'' ``I'm here,'' Grant said. ``Listen,'' Wu said. ``Can you see to the rear of the visitor building from where you are?'' Grant turned the radio off. Lex crawled back. ``Are we going to the cafeteria?'' she (them) said. ``Yes,'' Grant said. They got up, and started walking through the blowing mist in the lobby. ``I want a hamburger,'' Lex said. ``I don't think there's any electricity to cook with .'' ``Then ice cream.'' ``Tim, you'll have to stay with her (I) and help her (I).'' ``I will.'' ``I've got to leave for a while,'' Grant said. ``I know.'' Lex clutched his (Lex) hand, ``Turn on the lights,'' she (them) said. ``I can't,'' Tim said. ``There's no electricity.'' In phosphorescent green he (Tim) saw the tables and chairs. To the right, the glowing gr een cash register, and the rack with gum and candy. Tim stuffed the candy bars in his (Tim) pocket, and led L ex deeper into the dining room. She (them) tugged on his (Tim) band. ``I can't see spit,'' she (them) said. ``Just walk with me. Hold my hand.'' ``Then slow down.'' Beyond the tables and chairs was a pair of swinging doors with little round windows in them. They probably led to the kitchen. He (Tim) pushed one doo r open and it held wide. Ellie Sattler stepped outside the front door to the lodge, and felt the chilly mist on her (Sattler) face and legs. Her (Sattler) heart was thumping, even though she (Sattler) knew she (Sattler) was completely safe behind the fence. Directly ahead, she (Sattler) saw the heavy bars in th e fog. But she (Sattler) couldn't see much beyond the fence. Another twenty yards before the landscape turned milky white. And she (Sattler) didn't see any raptors at all. In fact, the gardens and trees were almost eerily silent. ``Hey!'' she (Sattler) shouted into the f og, tentatively. Muldoon leaned against the door frame. ``I doubt tha t'll do it,'' he (Muldoon) said. ``You've got to make a noise. Dinner is served!'' ``Very amusing,'' Ellie said. She (Ellie) glanced nervously t oward the roof. She (Ellie) saw no raptors. ``They don't understand English.

'' Muldoon grinned. '' (I)

The raptor disappeared, a white shadow and then cam e back, but it did not approach any closer, and it seemed strangely incurious about the noise coming from the lodge. She (Ellie) was starting to worry. Unless she (Ellie) could attract the rap tors to the lodge, Grant would be in danger.
``You're making too much noise,'' (unknown)
Ellie said.

`Bloody hell,'' Muldoon said. ``Well, you are.'' ``I know these animals-'' ``You're drunk,'' she (Ellie) said. ``Let me handle it.'' ``And how will you do that?'' At least as intelligent as chimps.'' ``They have good hearing?'' ``Yes, excellent.'' ``Maybe they'll know this sound,'' she (Ellie) said, and open ed the gate. She (Ellie) left it open. ``I wouldn't do that,'' Muldoon said. ``You're going t o do that, let me get the launcher.'' ``Get the launcher.'' He (Muldoon) sighed, remembering. ``Gennaro has the shells.'' ``Well, then,'' she (Ellie) said. ``Keep an eye out.'' And she (Ellie) went through the gate, stepping outside the bars. Her (Ellie) heart was pounding so hard she (Ellie) could bare ly feel her (Ellie) feet on the dirt. She (Ellie) moved away from the fence, and it disappeared frighteningly fa st in the fog. Soon it was lost behind her (Ellie). Just as she (Ellie) expected, Muldoon began shouting to her (Ellie) in drunken agitation. ``God damn it, girl, don't you do that,'' he (Muldoon) bellowed. ``Don't call me `girl,''' she (Ellie) shouted back. ``I'll call you any damn thing I want,'' Muldoon shou ted. She (Ellie) wasn't listening. She (Ellie) was turning slowly, her (Ellie) b ody tense, watching from all sides. She (Ellie) was at least twenty yards from the fence now, and she (Ellie) c ould see the mist drifting like a light rain past the foliage. She (Ellie) stayed away from the foliage. She (Ellie) moved through a world of shades of gray. The muscles in her (Ellie) legs and shoulders ached from the te nsion. Her (Ellie) eyes strained to see.

``Do you hear me, damn it?'' (unknown)
Muldoon bellowed. How good are these animals? she (Ellie) wondered. Good enou gh to cut off my retreat? There wasn't much distance back to the fence, not really- They attacked. There was no sound. The first animal charged from the foliage at the ba se of a tree to the left. It sprang forward and she (Ellie) turned to run. The second attacked from the oth er side, clearly intending to catch her (Ellie) as she (Ellie) ran, and it leapt into the air, claws raised to att ack, and she (Ellie) darted like a broken field runner, and

the animal crashed down in the dirt. Now she (Ellie) was ru nning flat out, not daring to look back, her (Ellie) breaths coming in deep gasps, seeing the bars of th e fence emerge from the haze, seeing Muldoon throw the gate wide, seeing him (Muldoon) reaching fo r her (Ellie), shouting to her (Ellie), grabbing her (Ellie) arm and pulling her (Ellie) through so hard she (Ellie) was yanked off her (Ellie) feet and fell to the ground. And she (Ellie) turned in time to see first one, then two-then tbree-animals hit the fence and snarl.

``Good work,'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)

``Christ, that was close! These bastar ds can jump!'' (She)
She (Ellie) got to her (Ellie) feet, looking at the scrapes and bru ises, the blood running down her (Ellie) leg. All she (Ellie) could think was: three animals here. And two on the roof. That meant one was still missing, somewhere.

he (Grant) said.

Their behavior had taken on the distinct quality of display, rather than serious attack.

Tim went through the swinging doors at the back of the dining room and entered the kitchen. A big stainless-steel table in the center of the room , a big stove with lots of burners to the left, and , beyond that, big walk-in refrigerators. Tim started opening the refrigerators, looking for ice cream. Smoke came out in the humid air as he (Tim) opened each o ne. ``How come the stove is on?'' Lex said, releasing his (Lex) hand. ``It's not on.'' ``They all have little blue flames.'' ``Those're pilot lights.'' ``What're pilot lights?'' They had an electric stove at home. ``Never mind,'' Tim said, opening another refrigerato r. ``But it means I can cook you something.'' In this next refrigerator, he (Tim) found all kinds of st uff, cartons of milk, and piles of vegetables, and a stack of T-bone steaks, fish-but no ice cream. ``You still want ice cream?'' ``I told you, didn't I?'' The next refrigerator was huge. A stainless steel d oor, with a wide horizontal handle. He (Tim) tugged on the handle, pulled it open, and saw a wal k-in freezer. It was a whole room, and it was freezing cold. ``Timmy ...'' ``Will you wait a minute?'' he (Tim) said, annoyed. ``I'm tr ying to find your ice cream.
``Timmy ... something's here.'' (She)
She (Tim) was whispering, and for a moment the last two w ords didn't register. Then Tim hurried back out of the freezer, seeing the edge of the wre athed in glowing green smoke. Lex stood by the steel worktable. She (Tim) was looking back to the ki tchen door. He (Lex) heard a low hissing sound, like a very large sna ke. The sound rose and fell softly. It was hardly audible. It might even be the wind, but he (Lex) s omehow knew it wasn't.
``Timmy,'' (she)
she (Tim) whispered,
``I'm scared.'' (she)
He (Lex) crept forward to the kitchen door and looked out . In the darkened dining room, he (Lex) saw the orderly green rectangular pattern of the tabletops. And moving smoothly among them, silent as a ghost except for the hissing of its breath, was a v elociraptor. In the darkness of the maintenance room, Grant felt along the pipes, moving back toward the ladder. It was difficult to make his (Grant) way in the dar k, and somehow he (Grant) found the noise of the generator disorienting. He (Grant) came to the ladder, and had started back up when he (Grant) realized there was something else in the room besides generator no ise. Grant paused, listening. It was a man shouting. It sounded like Gennaro.
``Where are you?'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant shouted.
``Over here, '' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``In the truck.'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant couldn't see any truck. He (Grant) squinted in the da rkness. He (Grant) looked out of the corner of his (Grant) eye. He (Grant) saw green glowing shapes, moving in the dar kness. Then he (Grant) saw the truck, and he (Grant) turned toward it. Tim found the silence chilling. The velociraptor was six feet tall, and powerfully built, although its strong legs and tail were hidden by the tables. Tim could see only the muscul ar upper torso, the two forearms held tightly alongside the body, the claws dangling. He (Tim) could se e the iridescent speckled pattern on the back. The velociraptor was alert; as it came forwar d, it looked from side to side, moving its head with abrupt, bird-like jerks. The head also bobbed up and down as it walked, and the long straight tail dipped, which heightened the impression of a b ird. A gigantic, silent bird of prey. The dining room was dark, but apparently the raptor could see well enough to move steadily forward. From time to time, it would bend over, low ering its head below the tables. Tim heard a rapid sniffing sound. Then the head would snap up, alertly, jerking back and fortb like a bird's. Tim watched until he (Tim) was sure the velociraptor was coming toward the kitchen. Was it following their scent? All the books said dinosaurs had a poor sense of smell, but this one seemed to do just fine. Anyway, what did books know ? Here was the real thing. Coming toward him (Tim). He (Tim) ducked back into the kitchen.
``Is something out there?'' (Lex)
Lex said. Tim didn't answer. He (Tim) pushed her (Tim) under a table in t he (Tim) corner, behind a large waste bin. He (Tim) leaned close to her (Tim) and whispered fiercely:
``Stay h ere!'' (He)
And then he (Tim) ran for the refrigerator. He (Tim) grabbed a handful of cold steaks and hurried bac k to the door. He (Tim) quietly placed the first of the steaks on the floor, then moved back a few step s, and put down the second... . Through his (Tim) goggles, he (Tim) saw Lex peeping around the bin. He (Lex) waved her (Tim) back. He (Lex) placed the third steak, and the fourth, moving deeper into the kitchen. The hissing was louder, and then the clawed hand gr ipped the door, and the big head peered cautiously around. The velociraptor paused at the entrance to the kitc hen. Tim stood in a half-crouch at the back of the room, near the far leg of the steel worktable. But he (Tim) had not had time to conceal himself; his (Tim) head an d shoulders still protruded over the tabletop. He (Tim) was in clear view of the velociraptor. Slowly, Tim lowered his (Tim) body, sinking beneath the t able... . The velociraptor jerked its head around, looking directly at Tim. Tim froze. He (Tim) was still exposed, but he (Tim) thought, Do n't move. The velociraptor stood motionless in the doorway. Sniff ing. It's darker here, Tim thought. He (Tim) can't see so well . It's making him (Tim) cautious. But now he (Tim) could smell the musty odor of the big re ptile, and through his (Tim) goggles he (Tim) saw the dinosaur silently yawn, throwing back its long snou t, exposing rows of razor-sharp teeth. The velociraptor stared forward again, jerking its head from side to side. The big eyes swiveled in the bony sockets. Tim felt his (Tim) heart pounding. Somehow it was worse t o be confronted by an animal like this in a kitchen, instead of the open forest. The size, the quick movements, the pungent odor, the hissing breath ... Up close, it was a much more frightening animal tha n the tyrannosaur. The Tyrannosaur was huge and powerful, but it wasn't especially smart. The velociraptor was man-size, and it was clearly quick and intelligent; Tim feared the searc hing eyes almost as much as the sharp teeth. The velociraptor sniffed. It stepped forward-moving directly toward Lex! It must smell her (Lex), somehow! Tim's heart thumped. The velociraptor stopped. It bent over slowly. He (Tim)'s found the steak. Tim wanted to bend down, to look below the table, b ut he (Tim) didn't dare move. He (Tim) stood frozen in a half-crouch, listening to the crunching sound. Th e dinosaur was eating it. Bones and all. The raptor raised its slender head, and looked arou nd. It sniffed. It saw the second steak. It moved quickly forward. It bent down. Silence. The raptor didn't eat it. The head came back up. Tim's legs burned from the c rouch, but he (Tim) didn't move. Why hadn't the animal eaten the second steak? A doz en ideas flashed through his (Tim) mind-it didn't like the taste of beef, it didn't like the c oldness, it didn't like the fact that the meat wasn 't alive, it smelled a trap, it smelled Lex, it smelle d Tim, it saw Tim- The velociraptor moved very quickly now. It found t he (Tim) third steak, dipped its head, looked up again, and moved on. Tim held his (Tim) breath. The dinosaur was now just a fe w feet from him (Tim), Tim could see the small twitches in the muscles of the flanks. He (Tim) could see the crusted blood on the claws of the hand. He (Tim) could see the fine pattern of striations within the spotted pattern, and the folds of skin in the neck below the jaw. The velociraptor sniffed. It jerked its head, and l ooked right at Tim. Tim nearly gasped with fright. Tim's body was rigid, tense. He (Tim) watched as the reptile eye moved, scanning the room. Another sniff. He (Tim)'s got me, Tim thought. Then the head jerked back to look forward, and the animal went on, toward the fifth steak. Tim thought, Lex please don't move please don't move wh atever you do please don't ... The velociraptor sniffed the steak, and moved on. I t was now at the open door to the freezer. Tim could see the smoke billowing out, curling alon g the floor toward the animal's feet. One big clawed foot lifted, then came down again, silently. The dinosaur hesitated. Too cold, Tim thought. He (Tim) won't go in there, it's too cold, he (Tim) won't go in he (Tim) won't go in he (Tim) won't go in... . The dinosaur went in. The head disappeared, then the body, then the stiff tail. Tim sprinted, flinging his (Tim) weight against the stain less-steel door of the locker, slamming it shut. It slammed on the tip of the tail! The door wouldn' t shut! The velociraptor roared, a terrifying loud sound. Inadvertently, Tim took a step back-the tail was gone! He (Tim) slammed the door shut and heard it click! Closed!
``Lex! Lex!'' (he)
he (Tim) was screaming. He (Tim) heard the raptor p ounding against the door, felt it thumping the steel. He (Tim) knew there was a flat steel knob insi de, and if the raptor hit that, it would knock the door open. They had to get the door locked.
``Lex!'' (Lex)
Lex was by his (Lex) side.
``What do you want!'' (Tim)
Tim leaned against the horizontal door handle, hold ing it shut.
``There's a pin! A little pin! Get the pin!'' (unknown)
The velociraptor roared like a lion, the sound muff led by the thick steel. It crashed its whole body against the door.
``I can't see anything!'' (Lex)
Lex shouted. The pin was dangling beneath the door handle, swing ing on a little metal chain.
``It's right there!'' (unknown)
``I can't see it!'' (she)
she (it) screamed, and then Tim realiz ed she (it) wasn't wearing the goggles.
``Feel for it!'' (He)
He (Tim) saw her (it) little hand reaching up, touching his (Tim), g roping for the pin, and with her (it) so close to him (Tim) he (Tim) could feel how frightened she (it) was, her (it) breat h in little panicky gasps as she (it) felt for the pin, and the velociraptor slammed against the door and i t opened-God, it opened-but the animal hadn't expected that and had already turned back fo r another try and Tim slammed the door shut again. Lex scrambled back, reached up in the darkne ss.
``I have it!'' (Lex)
Lex cried, clutching the pin in her (it) ha nd, and she (it) pushed it through the hole. It slid out again.
``From the top, put it in from the top!'' (She)
She (it) held it again, lifting it on the chain, swingin g it over the handle, and down. Into the hole. Locked. The velociraptor roared. Tim and Lex stepped back f rom the door as the dinosaur slammed into it again. With each impact, the heavy steel wa ll hinges creaked, but they held. Tim didn't think the animal could possibly open the door. The raptor was locked in. He (Tim) gave a long sigh.
``Let's go,'' (he)
he (Tim) said. He (Tim)

took her (it) hand, and they ran.

``You should have seen them,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said, as Grant led him (Gennaro) back out of the maintenance building.
``There must have been two dozen of them. Compys. I had to crawl into the truck to get away from them. They were all over the windshield. Just squatting there, waiting like buzzards. But they ran away when you came over.'' (unknown)

``What happened to the raptor that attacked you?'' (unknown)
Gr ant said.
``I don't know,'' (Gennaro/Donald/Donald Gennaro)
Gennaro said.
``Did it leave?'' (unknown)
``I didn't see. I got away, I think because it was i njured. I think Muldoon shot it in the leg and it was bleeding while it was in here. Then ... I don 't know. Maybe it went back outside. Maybe it died in here. I didn't see.'' (unknown)
``And maybe it's still in here,'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant said. Wu stared out the lodge window at the raptors beyon d the fence. They still seemed playful, making mock attacks at Ellie. The behavior had cont inued for a long time now, and it occurred to him (Wu) that it might be too long. It almost seemed as if they were trying to keep Ellie's attention, in the same way that she (Ellie) was trying to keep theirs. The behavior of the dinosaurs had always been a min or consideration for Wu. And rightly so: behavior was a second-order effect of DNA, like pro tein enfolding. You couldn't really predict behavior, and you couldn't really control it, excep t in very crude ways, like making an animal dependent on a dietary substance by withholding an enzyme. But, in general, behavioral effects were simply beyond the reach of understanding. You couldn't look at a DNA sequence and predict behavior. It was impossible. And that had made Wu's DNA work purely empirical. I t was a matter of tinkering, the way a modern workman might repair an antique grandfather clock. You were dealing with something out of the past, something constructed of ancient mater ials and following ancient rules. You couldn't be certain why it worked as it did, and it had been repaired and modified many times already, by forces of evolution, over eons of time. So, like th e workman who makes an adjustment and then sees if the clock runs any better, Wu would make an adjustment and then see if the animals behaved any better. And he (Wu) only tried to correct gr oss behavior: uncontrolled butting of the electrical fences, or rubbing the skin raw on tree trunks. Those were the behaviors that sent him (Wu) back to the drawing board. And the limits of his (Wu) science had left him (Wu) with a m ysterious feeling about the dinosaurs in the park. He (Wu) was never sure, never really sure at all, whether the behavior of the animals was historically accurate or not. Were they behaving as they really had in the past? It was an open question, ultimately unanswerable. And though Wu would never admit it, the discovery t hat the dinosaurs were breeding represented a tremendous validation of his (Wu) work. A breeding animal was demonstrably effective in a fundamental way; it implied that Wu had put al l the pieces together correctly. He (Wu) had re- created an animal millions of years old, with such precision that the creature could even reproduce itself. But, still, looking at the raptors outside, he (Wu) was troubled by the persistence of their behavior. Raptors were intelligent, and intelligent animals g ot bored quickly. Intelligent animals also formed plans, and- Harding came out into the hallway from Malcolm's ro om.
``Where's Ellie?'' (unknown)
``Still outside.'' (unknown)
``Better get her (Ellie) in. The raptors have left the skyli ght.'' (unknown)
``When?'' (Wu/Henry/Henry Wu)
Wu said, moving to the door.
``Just a moment ago,'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Harding said. Wu threw open the front door.
``Ellie! Inside, now!'' (She)

She (Raptors) looked over at him (Wu), puzzled.

``There's no proble m, everything's under control...'' (She)
``Now!'' (She)
She (Raptors) shook her (Raptors) head.
``I know what I'm doing,'' (she)
she (Raptors) sa id.
``Now, Ellie, damn it!'' (Muldoon/Robert Muldoon)
Muldoon didn't like Wu standing there with the door open, and he (Wu) was about to say so, when he (Wu) saw a shadow descend from above, and he (Wu) realized at once what had happened. Wu was yanked bodily out the door, and Muldoon heard Ellie screaming. Muldoon got to the door and looked out and saw that Wu was lying on his (Wu) back, h is body already torn open by the big claw, and the raptor was jerking its head, tugging at Wu' s intestines even though Wu was still alive, still feebly reaching up with his (Wu) hands to push the big h ead away, he (Wu) was being eaten while he (Wu) was still alive, and then Ellie stopped screaming and s tarted to run along the inside of the fence, and Muldoon slammed the door shut, dizzy with horror. I t had happened so fast! Harding said,
``He (I) jumped down from the roof?'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
Muldoon nodded. He (Muldoon) went to the window and looked ou t, and he (Muldoon) saw that the three raptors outside the fence were now running away. But they w eren't following Ellie. They were going back, toward the visitor center. Grant came to the edge of the maintenance building and peered forward, in the fog. He (Grant) could hear the snarls of the raptors, and they seemed to be coming closer. Now he (Grant) could see their bodies running past him (Grant). They were going to the vis itor center. He (Grant) looked back at Gennaro.

``No ch oice. We've got to turn on the computer.'' (Grant/Alan/Alan Grant)
Grant set out in the fog. After a moment, Gennaro followed. Ellie didn't stop to think. When the raptors droppe d inside the fence to attack Wu, she (Ellie) just turned and ran, as fast as she (Ellie) could, toward the far end o f the lodge. There was a space fifteen feet wide between the fence and the lodge. She (Ellie) ran, not hearing the animals pursuing her (Ellie), just hearing her (Ellie) own breath. She (Ellie) rounded the corner, saw a tree growing by the side of the building, and leapt, grabbing a branch, swinging up. She (Ellie) didn 't feel panic. She (Ellie) felt a kind of exhilaration as she (Ellie) kicked and saw her (Ellie) legs rise up In front of her (Ellie) face, and she (Ellie) hooked her (Ellie) legs over a branch farther up, tightened her (Ellie) gut, and pulled up quickl y. She (Ellie) was already twelve feet off the ground, and the raptors still weren't following her (Ellie), and she (Ellie) was beginning to feel pretty good, when she (Ellie) saw the first animal at the base of the tree. Its mouth was bloody, and bits of stringy flesh hung from its jaws. She (Ellie) continued to go up fast, hand over hand, just reaching and going, and she (Ellie) could almost see the top of the building. She (Ellie) looked down again. The two raptors were climbing the tree. Now she (Ellie) was at the level of the rooftop, she (Ellie) could see the gravel only four feet away, and the glass pyramids of the skylights, sticking up in the mist. There was a door on the roof; she (Ellie) could get inside. In a single heaving effort she (Ellie) flung he (its) rself through the air, and landed sprawling on the gravel. She (Ellie) scraped her (Ellie) face, but somehow the o nly sensation was exhilaration, as if it were a kind of game she (Ellie) was playing, a game she (Ellie) intended t o win. She (Ellie) ran for the door that led to the stairwell. Behind her (Ellie), she (Ellie) could hear the raptors s haking the branches of the tree. They were still in the tree. She (Ellie) reached the door, and twisted the knob. The doo r was locked. It took a moment for the meaning of that to cut thr ough her (Ellie) euphoria. The door was locked. She (Ellie) was on the roof and she (Ellie) couldn't get down. The door was locked. She (Ellie) pounded on the door in frustration, and then sh e ran for the far side of the roof, hoping to see a way down, but there was only the green outlin e of the swimming pool through the blowing mist. All around the pool was concrete decking. Ten , twelve feet of concrete. Too much for her (Ellie) to jump across. No other trees to climb down. No stair s. No fire escape. Nothing. Ellie turned back, and saw the raptors jumping easi ly to the roof. She (Ellie) ran to the far end of the building, hoping there might be another door there, but there wasn't. The raptors came slowly toward her (Ellie), stalking her (Ellie), s lipping silently among the glass pyramids. She (Ellie) looked down. The edge of the pool was ten feet away. Too far. The raptors were closer, starting to move apart, an d illogically she (Ellie) thought: Isn't this always the way? Some little mistake screws it all up. She (Ellie) stil l felt giddy, still felt exhilaration, and she (Ellie) somehow couldn't believe these animals were going t o get her (Ellie), she (Ellie) couldn't believe that now her (Ellie) life was going to end like this. It didn't seem pos sible. She (Ellie) was enveloped in a kind of protective cheerfulness. She (Ellie) just didn't believe it would happ en. The raptors snarled. Ellie backed away, moving to t he (Ellie) far end of the roof. She (Ellie) took a breath, and then began to sprint toward the edge. As she (Ellie) ra ced toward the edge, she (Ellie) saw the swimming pool, and she (Ellie) knew it was too far away but she (Ellie) thou ght, What the hell, and leapt into space. And fell. And with a stinging shock, she (Ellie) felt herself envelop ed in coldness. She (Ellie) was underwater. She (Ellie) had done it! She (Ellie) came to the surface and looked up at the roof, and saw the raptors looking down at her (Ellie). And she (Ellie) knew that, if she (Ellie) could do it, the raptors could do it, too. She (Ellie) splashed in the water and thought, Can raptors swim? But she (Ellie) wa s sure they could. They could probably swim like crocodiles. The raptors turned away from the edge of the roof. And then she (Ellie) heard Harding calling
``Sattler?'' (Harding/Dr. Harding)
and she (Ellie) realized he (Harding) had opened the roof door. The raptors were going toward him (Harding). Hurriedly, she (Ellie) climbed out of the pool and ran towa rd the lodge. Harding had gone up the steps to the roof two at a time, and he (Harding) had flung open the door without thinking.
``Sattler!'' (he)
he (Harding) shouted. And then he (Harding) stoppe d. Mist blew among the pyramids on the roof. The raptors were not in sight.
``Sattler!'' (He)
He (Harding) was so preoccupied with Sattler that it was a mo ment before he (Harding) realized his (Harding) mistake. He (Harding) should be able to see the animals, he (Harding) thought. ``Timmy ...'' (Lex)
